Washington, D.C.: The Washington Post. ==References== {{reflist|2}} == External links == {{Commons category|Counterfeit objects}} *[http://a-cappp.msu.edu/media-center/webinar-counterfeit-food-scope-and-threat National Food Safety and Toxicology Center] ''The Counterfeit Food Scope and Threat'' Seminar at the ''Michigan State University'' *[http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R43358.pdf Food fraud and "economically motivated adulteration" of food and food ingredients] at the [[Congressional Research Service]] *[http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlehtml/2012/cs/c2cs35138b Fingerprinting food: Current technologies for the detection of food adulteration and contamination] in the ''Chemical Society Reviews'' *[http://pubs.rsc.org/en/journals/articlecollectionlanding?sercode=an&themeid=dd305f52-68e5-44e6-8634-25d564d11c89 Detecting Food Authenticity and Integrity, Royal Society of Chemistry themed collection] *[http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlehtml/2015/ay/c5ay02048d?page=search Point-and-shoot: rapid quantitative detection methods for on-site food fraud analysis – moving out of the laboratory and into the food supply chain] *[https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-017-12263-0 Through-container, extremely low concentration detection of multiple chemical markers of counterfeit alcohol using a handheld SORS device] {{DEFAULTSORT:Counterfeit Consumer Goods}} [[Category:Commercial crimes]] [[Category:Counterfeit consumer goods| ]] [[Category:Authentication methods]]

page.title: Exploring the Ancient Greek Language and Culture

revision.text:
The '''Annual European Student Competition "Exploring the Ancient Greek Language and Culture"''' is an international [[competition]] held in [[Europe]] and in [[Mexico]]. It takes place yearly, and is to be considered among the most important high-school student competitions in classical languages held in Europe.
== Organisation == This competition is organised by the ''Greek Ministry of National Education and [[Religion|Religious]] Affairs'', and more specifically the ''Directorate of International Relations in Education'' and the Pedagogical Institute. Co-organisors are the ''Hellenic Language Heritage'', the ''Society of Greek Philologists'',[http://www.eephil.gr Society of Greek Philologists] the ''[[European Cultural Centre of Delphi]]'',[http://www.eccd.gr European Cultural Centre of Delphi] the ''Organization for the Internationalization of the [[Greek Language]]''[http://www.odeg.gr Organization for the Internalization of the Greek Language] and the ''Pan-Hellenic Association of Teachers for the Greek Language and Civilization''.[http://www.p-e-f.gr Panhellenic Associations of Teachers for the Greek Language] == Aims of the competition == The aim of the annual competition is the promotion of [[classical studies]] among those students of high schools throughout Europe where the [[Ancient Greek Language]] is taught. Furthermore, the organisors' intention is to emphasize the importance of classical studies throughout the acquisition and the study of the Ancient Greek world, to highlight the “European dimension” of ancient times, to emphasize the ties between the everlasting ideas and values of classical antiquity with the fundamental values of European history and civilization, to promote the Ancient Greek language as a means of expressing humanitarian ideas and values, in an era, when classical studies in Europe are declining, and last but not least to strengthen the classical studies in European schools by exchanging experiences between students and teachers.[http://www.ypepth.gr/en_ec_category6437.htm Greek Ministry of Education and Religious Affairs] The participants of the competition are students of the third grade of Greek Lyceums in all European countries, except Greece and Cyprus, and students of the last grade of High schools in all European countries, equivalent to the last (3rd) grade of Greek High schools, except Greece and Cyprus, as well as those of Mexico.
== Prizes == The prizes are the following: * 3. Certificate of Distinction * 2. Honorary Mention. * 1. The best student from each participating country is invited to a journey through Greece lasting a whole week, which is organized by the ''Hellenic Ministry of National Education and Religious Affairs''. == Winners == {| class="wikitable" |- class="hintergrundfarbe6" ! Year ! First place ! Second place ! Third place |- |2007 |Matthias Bartl, Austria |Sofija Hohnjec, Serbia |Adrien Dieudonné, France |} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.ypepth.gr/en_ec_category6437.htm Greek Ministry of Education] [[Category:Competitions]] [[Category:Secondary education]] [[Category:Classical philology]]

</noinclude>{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox artwork | title = Girl with Balloon | painting_alignment = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | wikidata = | image = Banksy Girl and Heart Balloon (2840632113).jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = Original mural on [[Waterloo Bridge]] in [[South Bank]] in 2004 | artist = [[Banksy]] | year = {{start date|2002}} | completion_date = <!-- For a more specific date (post-1583): {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | catalogue = | medium = | movement = | subject = | height_metric = <!-- (i.e. in metric units) --> | width_metric = | length_metric = | diameter_metric = | height_imperial = <!-- (i.e. in imperial units) --> | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = cm <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | imperial_unit = in <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | weight = | designation = | condition = | museum = | city = | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the coordinates (when known) of the artwork itself, i.e. not for the site, building, structure, etc where it is kept, otherwise leave blank (or omit): {{coord|LAT|LON|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | owner = | accession = | preceded_by = <!-- preceding work by the same artist --> | followed_by = <!-- next work by the same artist --> | module = | website = <!-- Official webpage/site only: {{URL|example.com}} --> }} '''''Girl with Balloon''''' (also, '''''Balloon Girl''''' or '''''Girl and Balloon''''') is a 2002-started London series of [[Stencil graffiti|stencil murals]] by the graffiti artist [[Banksy]], depicting a young girl with her hand extended toward a red heart-shaped [[Toy balloon|balloon]] carried away by the wind. The first work was on [[Waterloo Bridge]], and other murals were around London, though none remain there. Banksy has several times used variants of this design to support social campaigns: in 2005 about the [[Israeli West Bank barrier|West Bank barrier]], in 2014 about the [[Refugees of the Syrian Civil War|Syrian refugee crisis]], and also about the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017 UK election]]. A 2017 [[Samsung]] poll ranked ''Girl with Balloon'' as the United Kingdom's number one favourite artwork.
In 2018, a framed copy of the work spontaneously shredded during an auction, by way of a mechanical device Banksy had hidden in the frame. Banksy authenticated he was responsible for the shredding and gave the altered piece a new name, ''[[Love Is in the Bin]]''. Sotheby said it was "the first work in history ever created during a live auction."
==History== [[File:BANKSY LONDON.jpg|thumb|right|This variation in London, seen above in 2006, was the last one in the city, painted over in 2007.]] The first mural was in 2002 at the stairs for [[Waterloo Bridge]] on the [[South Bank]] side. A number of other mural versions were also created in London, though, mostly painted over, none of the works by Banksy are remaining.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hxb9BgAAQBAJ&pg=PT24|title=Banksy Locations & Tours Volume 1: A Collection of Graffiti Locations and Photographs in London, England|last=Bull|first=Martin|date=2011-11-01|publisher=PM Press|isbn=9781604863208|language=en}}</ref> A 2004 version of the mural was at an east London shop in [[Shoreditch]], sold in 2007 for £37,200 at [[Sotheby's]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/6340109.stm|title=Record price for Banksy bomb art|date=8 February 2007|accessdate=17 December 2015|publisher=[[BBC News]]}}</ref> and was removed by the Sincura Group in 2014 and sold for £500,000 in September 19 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-london-26022513 |title=London Banksy Girl and Balloon mural to be removed |last=McDermott |first=Josephine |date=7 February 2014 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=7 March 2016}}</ref>
Several sets of [[Edition (printmaking)|limited edition prints]] of the work were produced, which became valuable over time. An initial set of 25 signed prints was produced in 2003,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/news/london/2018-03-08/banksy-girl-and-balloon-canvas-smashes-auction-estimate/|title=Banksy 'Girl and Balloon' canvas smashes auction estimate|work=ITV News|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bonhams.com/auctions/24744/lot/44/|title=Bonhams : Banksy (British, born 1975) Girl and Balloon 2003|website=www.bonhams.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-10-16}}</ref> while a set of 150 signed prints and a set of 600 unsigned prints were produced in 2004/2005.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.picturesonwalls.com/|title=picturesonwalls|website=www.picturesonwalls.com|access-date=2018-10-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.myartbroker.com/artist/banksy/girl-with-balloon/|title=Banksy Girl With Balloon (2004), Meaning & Description, My Art Broker|work=My Art Broker|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In November 2015, one of the signed set of 150 was auctioned for £56,250, more than twice its estimated value.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/news/westcountry/2015-11-25/banksy-print-makes-more-than-a-picasso-at-auction/|title=Banksy print makes more than a Picasso at auction|work=ITV News|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en}}</ref>
A 2009 version was sprayed directly onto the cardboard backing of an [[IKEA|Ikea]] frame.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-17559526|title=Banksy artworks sell for £400,000|date=2012-03-30|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bonhams.com/auctions/20195/lot/237/|title=Bonhams : Banksy (b. 1975) Girl and Balloon 2009 signed and inscribed For Mike. Thanks on the reverse stencil spray paint on cardboard, in integral frame 54 by 74 cm. 21 1/4 by 29 1/8 in. This work was executed in 2009.|website=www.bonhams.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-10-16}}</ref>
In August 2005, Banksy included it as part of a series of murals on the [[Israeli West Bank barrier|West Bank barrier]], a variation called ''Balloon Debate'' of the girl [[Cluster ballooning|floating above]] the wall while holding onto a bunch of balloons.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20171215-how-a-balloon-can-be-an-emblem-of-hope|title=How a balloon can be an emblem of hope|last=Grovier|first=Kelly|date=2017-12-15|website=BBC|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thecrimson.com/column/the-art-of-protest/article/2014/3/26/the-art-of-protest-banksy/|title=Banksy and the Wall|last=Kim|first=Adela H.|date=2014-03-26|website=The Harvard Crimson|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/opinion/banksy-sothebys-art-shredded-1368280|title=Can We Just Admit That Banksy's Art-Shredding Stunt Is Actually Really Good?|last=Davis|first=Ben|date=2018-10-10|work=artnet News|access-date=2018-10-15|language=en-US}}</ref>
In March 2014, the third anniversary of the Syria conflict, Banksy reworked the painting to depict a Syrian refugee and added the [[hashtag]] #WithSyria. On 13 March, the image was projected on the [[Eiffel Tower]] and [[Nelson's Column]]. An animated video was released, featuring animation based on Banksy's work, narration by [[Idris Elba]], and music by [[Elbow (band)|Elbow]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/banksy-reworks-girl-with-heart-balloon-to-mark-third-anniversary-of-syria-conflict-9187047.html |title=Banksy reworks girl with heart balloon to mark third anniversary of Syria conflict |author=Jess Denham |date=12 March 2014 |work=The Independent |accessdate=7 March 2016}}</ref> In the following weeks, the singer [[Justin Bieber]] got a tattoo based on the original art and posted a picture of it on Instagram before deleting it. Banksy posted this picture on his Facebook page with the comment "Controversial".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2014/03/18/justin-bieber-banksy-tattoo-graffiti-artist_n_4984389.html |title=Justin Bieber's Banksy Tattoo Blasted By The Graffiti Artist, Sort Of |date=18 March 2014 |work=The Huffington Post UK |accessdate=7 March 2016}}</ref>
In July 2017, a [[Samsung]] poll of 2,000 people from the United Kingdom asked participants to rank twenty pieces of British art. The poll's results listed ''Balloon Girl'' as the people's number one favourite artwork.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-40717821 |title=Banksy's balloon girl chosen as nation's favourite artwork |date=26 July 2017 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=29 July 2017}}</ref> ===United Kingdom general election controversy=== In early June 2017 before the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|United Kingdom general election]], Banksy introduced a variant of ''Girl with Balloon'' with the balloon coloured with the [[Union Jack]] design.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.itv.com/news/2017-06-03/banksy-offers-free-art-print-to-those-who-vote-against-the-conservatives/ |title=Banksy risks breaking election law with offer of art prints for anti-Conservative voters |publisher=[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] |date=3 June 2017 |accessdate=10 June 2017}}</ref> Banksy initially offered to send a free print of his art to registered voters in certain constituencies who could offer photographic proof they had voted against the [[Tories (British political party)|Tories]]. The offer included a disclaimer: "This print is a souvenir piece of campaign material, it is in no way meant to influence the choices of the electorate."<ref>{{cite web |last=O'Connor |first=Roisin |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/general-election-2017-banksy-free-print-vote-against-conservative-party-theresa-may-eu-brexit-a7772341.html |title=Banksy is offering free art to people who vote against the Tories |date=4 June 2017 |work=Independent |accessdate=10 June 2017}}</ref> Banksy cancelled this offer on 6 June 2017 after the [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]] warned him it could violate election [[bribery]] laws and invalidate the election's results in those constituencies.<ref>{{cite web |last=Morris |first=Steven |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/jun/06/bansky-free-election-artwork-bristol-withdrawn |title=Banksy forced to withdraw offer to send free artwork to non-Tory voters |date=6 June 2017 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=10 June 2017}}</ref>
===Shredding at auction=== {{Main|Love Is in the Bin}} On 5 October 2018, a 2006 framed copy of the artwork was auctioned at Sotheby's selling for £1,042,000 – a record high for the artist.<ref name=martinez/> Moments after the closing bid, the artwork began to self-destruct by means of a hidden mechanical paper shredder that Banksy had built into the frame bottom.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-bristol-45770028 |title=Banksy artwork shreds itself after £1m sale at Sotheby's |date=6 October 2018 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=6 October 2018}}</ref> Only the lower half shredded. Banksy released an image of the shredding on Instagram with the words "Going, going gone..".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2018/oct/06/banksy-sothebys-auction-prank-leaves-art-world-in-shreds-girl-with-balloon |title=Banksy auction prank leaves art world in shreds |first=Chris |last=Johnston|date= 6 October 2018 |work=The Guardian }}</ref> Sotheby's said "We have not experienced this situation in the past where a painting spontaneously shredded",<ref name=martinez>{{cite web |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/apos-appears-just-got-banksy-144105925.html |title='It Appears We Just Got Banksy-ed.' Art Piece Self Destructs After Being Sold for Over $1 Million |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |agency=[[Yahoo! News]] |author=Gina Martinez |date=October 6, 2018 |accessdate=October 7, 2018}}</ref> leading some market watchers to speculate the remains of the painting will be worth even more.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.apnews.com/5f8911d839ce42e6a2ffc62f2cdf6074 |title=Banksy artwork self-destructs just after $1.4 million sale |publisher=Associated Press |author=Jill Lawless |date=7 October 2018 |accessdate=8 October 2018}}</ref> Banksy released a video of the shredding and how the shredder was installed into the frame in case the picture ever went up for auction.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/video/2018/oct/07/banksy-publishes-video-detailing-auction-prank-plan-video |title= Banksy publishes video detailing auction stunt plan – video |date=7 October 2018 |work=The Guardian}}</ref>
The woman who won the bidding at the auction decided to go through with the purchase. The partially shredded work has been given a new title, ''Love Is in the Bin'', and was authenticated by Banksy's authentication body Pest Control. Sotheby's released a statement that called it "the first artwork in history to have been created live during an auction."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2018/oct/11/woman-who-bought-shredded-banksy-artwork-will-go-through-with-sale |title=Woman who bought shredded Banksy artwork will go through with purchase |first=Mattha|last= Busby|date=11 October 2018|work=The Guardian }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.artnet.com/market/banksy-re-authenticates-shredded-1-4-million-european-buyer-will-keep-1369852 |title=Banksy Authenticates and Renames His Shredded $1.4 Million Painting—Which the Buyer Plans to Keep|first=Eileen|last= Kinsella|date=11 October 2018 |work=artnet}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

'''Harry Samit''' is a [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] [[Special Agent]] based at the [[List of FBI Field Offices|FBI Field Office]] in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]]. He is a former [[United States Navy]] [[Office of Naval Intelligence|Naval Intelligence]] Officer who participated in an aviation indoctrination course (he does not hold Naval Aviator wings). Samit's aeronautical ratings consist of an Air Transport Canada (Canadian) certified [[private pilot|private pilot license.]] Samit is most noted for arresting [[Zacarias Moussaoui]] on August 16, 2001.
Samit became aware of Moussaoui because of Clancy Prevost,<ref>[http://rakemag.com/2005/04/grounded-man/2/ The Grounded Man] ''Rake Magazine'' May 2005, retrieved Feb 6, 2017</ref> a [[certified flight instructor]] at the Pan-Am International Flight Academy in [[Eagan, Minnesota]]. Moussaoui had enrolled for training in a [[747-400]] [[flight simulator]] at the school on August 13 but his behavior during instruction alarmed Prevost, who did not believe that Moussaoui was just a wealthy individual interested in flying [[Wide-body aircraft|jumbo jets]]. At Prevost's urging, the flight school contacted the Minneapolis FBI Field Office, and Samit was one of the special agents assigned to investigate Moussaoui.
Moussaoui was arrested by INS Special Agents for a [[Visa (document)|visa]] violation on August 16 but, because the arrest was effected outside the Residence Inn where Moussaoui had been staying, Samit had no legal right to search the hotel room and its contents without Moussaoui's consent. Moussaoui denied consent, so Samit could only search Moussaoui and his car. Samit found a small knife in Moussaoui's left pocket and another knife in the car.<ref>[http://ktwbtv.trb.com/la-na-moussa10mar10,0,7797069.story?coll=ktwb-home-5] ''KTWB-TV'', retrieved March 27, 2006</ref>
As a certified private pilot himself, Samit was suspicious, suspecting that Moussaoui was plotting an act of international [[terrorism]] against the [[United States]]. He therefore sought permission to search Moussaoui's belongings which were known to include several bags and suitcases, and a [[laptop computer]]. The first application to obtain a criminal [[search warrant]] was denied by FBI Headquarters on the ground of insufficient evidence. A second application to search was made under the ''[[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act]]'' of 1978, but this was also denied. The FBI did obtain a search warrant for the belongings, but only after the [[September 11th attacks]]. The Minneapolis Field Office had received a report from Moussaoui's home government of [[France]] that linked him to [[Islamic terrorism]], but the FBI Headquarters in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] did not believe that evidence was sufficient to present to the FISA court for a search warrant. On the question of using foreign government intelligence to validate a request for a domestic search warrant through the FISA court, it is unclear if the Field Office could have appealed administratively to the White House National Security Council. Had the belongings been opened before September 11, knives, flight manuals, and other clues would have been found.<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/news/printedition/front/la-na-moussa21mar21,1,5398407.story?coll=la-headlines-frontpage Agent Faults FBI on 9/11] ''The Los Angeles Times'' March 21, 2006, retrieved March 27, 2006</ref> Whether these clues would have sparked a national emergency or simply been treated like the August 6 memo entitled ''[[Bin Ladin Determined To Strike in US]]'' is subject to debate.
When FBI Headquarters denied both Samit's application for search powers, he initiated a process to notify the [[Federal Aviation Administration]] (FAA) of his suspicions of possible [[aircraft hijacking]] attempts, but FBI Headquarters censored the memo. Relying on personal contacts, Samit then met with a Minneapolis FAA official, but that official did not pursue Samit's leads.
"I am so desperate to get into his computer, I'll take anything,"<ref name="NZ_Herald_10373766">{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/story.cfm?c_id=2&ObjectID=10373766 |title=September 11 alert was ignored, says FBI agent |date=March 22, 2006 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=October 2, 2011}}</ref> Samit wrote in an e-mail on September 10, 2001.
In March 2006, during Moussaoui's death sentence trial, Samit testified that he had spent the time between August 16 and September 11 trying to warn U.S. officials about the possibility of terrorist actions involving the hijacking of aircraft. Four such actions occurred in the United States on September 11, 2001. Samit testified under oath that "[[criminal negligence]], [[obstruction of justice|obstruction]] and careerism" <ref>[http://www.sacbee.com/content/news/crime/story/14232880p-15054935c.html Moussaoui alerts ignored, agent says]{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''The Sacramento Bee'' March 21, 2006, retrieved March 27, 2006</ref> by superiors at FBI Headquarters in [[Washington, DC]] thwarted an opportunity to prevent the [[September 11th attacks]].
[[Mohamad Elzahabi]] was "branded an [[al-Qaeda]] terrorist" and arrested by Samit on April 16, 2004.<ref name="colin">{{cite news |last=Freze |first=Colin |work=[[The Globe and Mail]] |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/opinions/jailed-arab-details-ties-to-tortured-canadians/article1285350/ |title=Jailed Arab details ties to tortured Canadians |date=September 11, 2009}}</ref>
