In other words, give Ashford, a clear crowd favorite, more to do". The musical's Broadway debut received mixed to positive reviews.{{cite web| url=http://www.didhelikeit.com/shows/kinky-boots-reviews.html_| title=Did he like it|accessdate=August 7, 2015|date=August 7, 2015|work=[[DidHeLikeIt.com]]| author=DidHeLikeIt.com}}{{dead link|date=August 2015}} The show was awarded a "Critic's Pick" designation by ''The New York Times, Time Out New York'' and ''New York Magazine'', and was included in ''Entertainment Weekly'' magazine's "Must See" list.{{cite web|title=''Kinky Boots'' Musical Website| url=http://kinkybootsthemusical.com|accessdate=December 15, 2013}} [[Ben Brantley]] of ''The New York Times'' gave a warm review, calling it "inspired" and comparing the work to other successful recent Broadway musicals: "Like ''[[The Full Monty (musical)|The Full Monty]]'' (choreographed by Mr. Mitchell) and ''[[Billy Elliot the Musical]]'', it is set in a hard-times British factory town, where jobs are in jeopardy and spirits need lifting. Like ''La Cage aux Folles'' and ''[[Priscilla, Queen of the Desert (musical)|Priscilla Queen of the Desert]]'', it presents drag queens as the show’s official spirit lifters. And like ''Hairspray'', the musical this production most resembles in tone, ''Kinky Boots'' is about finding your passion, overcoming prejudice and transcending stereotypes." Brantley wrote that Lauper's "love- and heat-seeking score" wowed with her "trademark ... mix of sentimentality and eccentricity", and that the costumes and boots courtesy of Gregg Barnes made for "big red scene stealers". He also praised “Raise You Up/Just Be,” as "one of the best curtain numbers since '[[You Can't Stop the Beat]]' sent ''Hairspray'' audiences dancing out of the theater.” Brantley, however, did not extend his praise to Fierstein's script, writing that his "sticky, sermonizing side" comes through in the second half, where "all the clichés stand naked before you."{{cite web|url=http://theater.nytimes.com/2013/04/05/theater/reviews/kinky-boots-the-harvey-fierstein-cyndi-lauper-musical.html|title=High Spirits, Higher Heels: ''Kinky Boots'', the Harvey Fierstein-Cyndi Lauper Musical| accessdate=April 29, 2013| date=April 4, 2013|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Brantley, Ben}} The theatre critic for ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]] New York'' called the show "the very model of a modern major musical."{{cite news|last=Feldman|first=Adam| title=''Kinky Boots''|url=http://www.timeout.com/newyork/theater/kinky-boots|accessdate=December 15, 2013|newspaper=[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]] New York|date=April 4, 2013}} The [[Associated Press]] termed it "a big ol’ sweet love story about sons, the families we make and red patent leather. ... Thank goodness for Harvey Fierstein – he spins theatrical magic", but despite criticisms of the script the “perpetual cheer-churning machine” that is Kinky Boots certainly serves an important end goal; to empower not just its central characters, but the entire audience, in the spirit of acceptance.{{cite news|last=Brantley |first=Ben |title=“‘Kinky Boots’ With Wayne Brady as a Cross-Dresser You Could Take Home to Mother” |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/28/theater/kinky-boots-with-wayne-brady-a-cross-dresser-you-could-take-home-to-mother.html?_r=0 |accessdate=May 15, 2017 |newspaper=[[New York Times]] New York|date=December 27, 2015}} According to Grossman, Kinky Boots facilitates the retraining of the eye to gender conventions and “repositions the marginalised figure as central to the spectacle of mass theatre... enacting a shift in the perspective of the viewer”.{{cite book |last=Grossman |first=Julie |title=Literature, Film and Their Hideous Progeny|date=2015 |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan UK |page=136–141 }} The finale “Raise You Up/Just Be” epitomises the empowerment of the individual, empowerment to “Just Be” regardless of the “oppressive gender roles directly connected to patriarchal views of legacy and inheritance”{{cite book |last=Grossman |first=Julie |title=Literature, Film and Their Hideous Progeny|date=2015 |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan UK |page=136–141}} under which Charlie and Lola initially suffer. Robert|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/entertainment/the-scene/kinky-boots-review-201455191.html|title=Cyndi Lauper and Harvey Fierstein Don Their ''Kinky Boots''|publisher=[[WNBC-TV]]|date=April 5, 2013|accessdate=December 16, 2013}} In 2014, Kinky Boots began a United States national tour, which has also garnered mostly positive reviews.{{cite web| url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Review-Roundup-KINKY-BOOTS-on-Tour-20141114|title=Review Roundup: KINKY BOOTS on Tour!|accessdate=November 14, 2014|date=August 10, 2015|work=[[Broadway World]]}} ''[[Democrat and Chronicle]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/news/2015/05/13/review-kinky-boots/27255273/|title=Review: 'Kinky Boots;| accessdate=August 10, 2015| date=May 13, 2015|work=[[Democrat and Chronicle]]|author=Morphy, Marcia}} raved, “Flashy, funny and uplifting, Kinky Boots has appeal — and lots of it — for all ‘ladies, gentleman and those who are yet to make up their mind.’” BroadwayWorld Los Angeles{{cite web|author=Grigware, Don|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/los-angeles/article/BWW-Reviews-Pantages-Shows-Off-KINKY-BOOTS-20141113?PageSpeed=noscript|title=BWW Reviews: Pantages shows off KINKY BOOTS|work=[[Broadway World]]|date=November 13, 2014|accessdate=August 10, 2015}} offered “praise to the entire triple threat ensemble!“ The Republic{{cite web|author=Lengel, Kerry|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/entertainment/arts/2014/09/17/theater-review-kinky-boots-asu-gammage/15777369/|title=Theatre Review: Kinky Boots at ASU Gammage|work=[[AZ Central]]|date=September 17, 2014|accessdate=August 10, 2015}} countered, “Despite the fiery showstopper "Sex Is in the Heel," however, "Kinky Boots" is surprisingly short on sex appeal, and the cheerleaderish troupe of drag queens called Angels don't have any of the transgressive appeal of the Cagelles from Fierstein's earlier hit "La Cage aux Folles." CBS Minnesota{{cite web|author=Fraser, Katie|url=http://minnesota.cbslocal.com/2015/07/29/mnfusion-kinky-boots-is-loud-proud-and-a-tubular-sensation/|title='Kinky Boots' is a loud, proud, tubular sensation|work=[[CBS Local]]|date=July 29, 2015|accessdate=August 10, 2015}} summed it up as “loud, proud and a tubular sensation.” The London production received mostly raves, with the [[London Evening Standard]] writing, "The thigh's the limit for this high-kicking London musical," calling it "a glorious high-kicking romp," and adding that "...its energy is infectious."{{cite web| url=https://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/theatre/kinky-boots-theatre-review-thigh-s-the-limit-for-this-high-kicking-musical-a2948621.html|title=Kinky Boots, Adelphi Theatre review: Thigh’s the limit for this high-kicking London musical|accessdate=October 5, 2015|date=September 16, 2015|work=[[The London Evening Standard]]}} [[Time Out London]] called it "dazzling, fabulously sassy and uplifting," explaining "It's not all glitz and high-kicks...there are some grittier moments that give the show an edgier feel."{{cite web|author=Grover, Natalie|url=http://www.timeout.com/london/theatre/kinky-boots|title=The best musical set in a British factory since 'Made in Dagenham'|accessdate=October 5, 2015|date=September 16, 2015|work=[[Time Out London]]}} And [[Digital Spy]] proclaimed it "hilarious, heartwarming, and a hell of a lot of fun," offering special praise for the show's star: "Matt Henry...truly steals the show...He is utterly commanding in the role, and you instantly root for him."{{cite web|author=Eames, Tom|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/celebrity/review/a668419/kinky-boots-review-the-voice-uks-matt-henry-is-your-new-west-end-hero.html#~pqsJVCceUfCAwM|title=The Voice UK's Matt Henry is your new West End hero. |accessdate=October 5, 2015|date=September 16, 2015|work=[[Digital Spy]]}} Kinky Boots adds to the public discourse of gender, and its flexibility and fluidity. The prevalence of drag culture in mainstream media has introduced a step of separation between femininity and being female.{{Cite book|title=The Constitution of Transgender Masculinities through Performance|last=McNamara|first=Catherine|publisher=Queen Mary, University of London|year=2009|isbn=|location=|pages=137–151}} ==Awards and nominations== {{Further|List of awards and nominations for the musical Kinky Boots}} ''Matilda'' had been the pre-Award season favorite, but as the season progressed, it became clear that ''Kinky Boots'' and the revival of ''[[Pippin (musical)|Pippin]]'' would provide serious competition.{{cite news| last=Healy|first=Patrick|title=Curtain's Up On A Real Race|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/07/theater/theaterspecial/predictions-from-tony-award-voters.html|accessdate=December 15, 2013|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 7, 2013}} Early in the 2013 awards season, ''Kinky Boots'' did well, receiving [[Drama League Award]] nominations for Distinguished Production of a Musical and Distinguished Performance, for both Porter and Sands,{{cite web| url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/177204-Nominees-Announced-for-79th-Annual-Drama-League-Awards| title=Nominees Announced for 79th Annual Drama League Awards| accessdate=April 27, 2013| date=April 25, 2013| work=[[Playbill]]| author=Gans, Andrew| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130426235718/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/177204-Nominees-Announced-for-79th-Annual-Drama-League-Awards| archivedate=April 26, 2013| df=mdy-all}} and winning for Distinguished Production.{{cite web|author=Gans, Andrew |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/178072-Kinky-Boots-Pippin-Vanya-and-Sonia-Virginia-Woolf-and-More-Win-Drama-League-Awards |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130615172250/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/178072-Kinky-Boots-Pippin-Vanya-and-Sonia-Virginia-Woolf-and-More-Win-Drama-League-Awards |dead-url=yes |archive-date=June 15, 2013 |title=''Kinky Boots'', ''Pippin'', ''Vanya and Sonia'', ''Virginia Woolf'' and More Win Drama League Awards |work=[[Playbill]] |accessdate=May 17, 2013 |date=May 17, 2013 }} The show received nine [[Outer Critics Circle Award]] nominations, winning three, including Outstanding New Broadway Musical, Outstanding New Score and Outstanding Actor in a Musical (Porter).{{cite web |url= http://www.playbill.com/news/article/177151-{{urlencode:Pippin Is Big Winner of 2012-13 Outer Critics Circle Awards}} | title=''Pippin'' Is Big Winner of 2012-13 Outer Critics Circle Awards| accessdate=May 13, 2013 |date=May 13, 2013 |work=[[Playbill]] |author= Gans, Andrew}} The musical received only two [[Drama Desk Award]] nominations, however, and only one win: Porter for [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Actor in a Musical|Outstanding Actor in a Musical]].{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/178137-Billy-Porter-Andrea-Martin-Pippin-Matilda-Vanya-and-Sonia-Win-Drama-Desk-Awards |title=Billy Porter, Andrea Martin, ''Pippin'', ''Matilda'', ''Vanya and Sonia'' Win Drama Desk Awards |accessdate=May 20, 2013 |date=May 19, 2013 |work=[[Playbill]] |author=Hetrick, Adam |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130605004524/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/178137-Billy-Porter-Andrea-Martin-Pippin-Matilda-Vanya-and-Sonia-Win-Drama-Desk-Awards |archivedate=June 5, 2013 |df= }} ''New York Times'' theatre writer Patrick Healy, however, reported that some Tony voters found ''Matilda'' "dark" and "a bit chilly", and accurately predicted that "while the cleverness of ''Matilda'' may be enough to win best book, the warmth of ''Kinky Boots'' will be enough to score an upset and take the top Tony for best musical." ''Kinky Boots'' received a season-high 13 [[Tony Awards|Tony Award]] nominations.{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/178918-Kinky-Boots-Vanya-and-Sonia-Pippin-and-Virginia-Woolf-Are-Big-Winners-at-67th-Annual-Tony-Awards |title=''Kinky Boots'', ''Vanya and Sonia'', ''Pippin'' and ''Virginia Woolf'' Are Big Winners at 67th Annual Tony Awards |accessdate=June 10, 2013 |date=June 9, 2013 |work=[[Playbill]] |author=Purcell, Carey |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130611034933/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/178918-Kinky-Boots-Vanya-and-Sonia-Pippin-and-Virginia-Woolf-Are-Big-Winners-at-67th-Annual-Tony-Awards |archivedate=June 11, 2013 |df= }} ''Matilda'', which ''The New York Times'' described as the "unalloyed critical hit" of the season, received 12 nominations, 11 of them in the same categories as ''Kinky Boots''.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/01/theater/theaterspecial/its-kinky-boots-vs-matilda-in-tony-nominations.html|title=It's ''Kinky Boots'' vs. ''Matilda'' in Tony Nominations| accessdate=November 10, 2013|date=April 30, 2013|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Healy, Patrick}} In addition to its critical success, ''Matilda'' had won the Drama Desk Award for outstanding musical and had set a record by winning the most Olivier Awards in history.{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-17721379 | title=''Matilda'' Musical Breaks Olivier Awards Record | publisher=BBC | date=April 15, 2012 | accessdate=November 20, 2013}} Nevertheless, ''Kinky Boots'' won a season-high six Tonys, including [[Tony Award for Best Musical|Best Musical]], which the press described as an upset, and Lauper's win for [[Tony Award for Best Original Score|Best Score]] made her the first woman to win alone in that category.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/10/theater/theaterspecial/at-tonys-kinky-boots-and-matilda-vie-for-best-musical.html?_r=0| title=''Kinky Boots'' Dances To The Top Of The Tonys| accessdate=November 9, 2013| date=June 10, 2013| work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Healy, Patrick}} The creative team are Americans, and reviewer David Cote, an American writing in ''The Guardian'', judged that the show's win was a case of "the balance of love going to a homegrown American musical, ''Kinky Boots'', over the British import ''Matilda''."{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2013/jun/10/tony-awards-matilda-kinky-boots|title=Tony Awards 2013: ''Matilda'' Left Wanting As ''Kinky Boots'' Dances To Victory: Tony Voters Stuck To The American Side Of Broadway – Even If ''Kinky Boots'' Came With An English Pedigree|accessdate=November 9, 2013|date=June 10, 2013|work=[[The Guardian]]|author=Cote, David}} The other Tony wins were for best actor (Porter), sound design (Shivers), choreography (Mitchell) and orchestrations (Oremus). Fierstein, Sands, Ashford, Mitchell (as director) and the three other designers were all nominated but did not win. ''Kinky Boots'' also won the 2013 [[Artios Award]] for Outstanding Achievement in Casting in the Broadway musical category.{{cite web|url=http://www.castingsociety.com/awards/artios |title=Artios Awards |publisher=[[Casting Society of America]] |accessdate=November 20, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502160504/http://www.castingsociety.com/awards/artios |archivedate=May 2, 2013 |df= }} The West End production won the Evening Standard Radio 2 Audience Award for Best New Musical, which was based on voting by the public at the 2015 [[Evening Standard Theatre Awards]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-34896188|title=Nicole Kidman and James McAvoy win at Evening Standard Theatre Awards|accessdate=November 25, 2015|date=November 23, 2015|publisher=[[BBC News]]|author=Masters, Tim}} The show earned seven nominations for the [[2016 Laurence Olivier Awards]], which was second to a revival of ''[[Gypsy (musical)|Gypsy]]'', which earned eight nominations.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/legit/news/olivier-awards-nominations-2016-1201718105/|title=‘Kinky Boots’ and Kenneth Branagh Rack Up Nominations for London’s Olivier Awards|accessdate=March 25, 2016|date=February 29, 2016|publisher=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|author=Cox, Gordon}} ''Kinky Boots'' won three Olivier Awards: [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best New Musical|Best New Musical]], [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Actor in a Musical|Best Actor in a Musical]] and [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Costume Design|Best Costume Design]], trailing only ''Gypsy'''s four awards.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/backstage-buzz-kinky-boots-walks-away-with-olivier-awards-1459810519|title=Backstage Buzz: ‘Kinky Boots’ Walks Away With Olivier Awards: Plus: A tribute to Ethel Merman and Broadway box office hits and misses|accessdate=April 14, 2016|date=April 4, 2016|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|author=Catton, Pia}} ==Recordings== {{main article|Kinky Boots (Broadway cast album)}} A Broadway original cast album, produced by Lauper, Oremus and William Wittman{{cite web | url=http://www.masterworksbroadway.com/news/kinky-boots-cast-album-coming-soon | title=''Kinky Boots'' Cast Album Coming Soon! | publisher=[[Masterworks Broadway]] | work=masterworksbroadway.com | date=March 8, 2013 | accessdate=June 7, 2013}} was released on May 28, 2013.{{cite web | url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/178364-Everybody-Say-Yeah-Kinky-Boots-Broadway-Cast-Album-Released-May-28 | title="Everybody Say Yeah": ''Kinky Boots'' Broadway Cast Album Released May 28 | author=Hetrick, Adam | publisher=[[Playbill]] | work=playbill.com | date=May 28, 2013 | accessdate=June 7, 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130605052759/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/178364-Everybody-Say-Yeah-Kinky-Boots-Broadway-Cast-Album-Released-May-28 | archivedate=June 5, 2013 | df=mdy-all }} It premiered at number one on the [[Billboard charts|Billboard]] Cast Albums Chart and number fifty-one on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart,{{cite web | url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/178853-Kinky-Boots-Broadway-Cast-Album-Debuts-at-1-on-Billboard-Chart | title=''Kinky Boots'' Broadway Cast Album Debuts at #1 on Billboard Chart | publisher=[[Playbill]] | work=playbill.com | date=June 7, 2013 | accessdate=June 7, 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130611164854/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/178853-Kinky-Boots-Broadway-Cast-Album-Debuts-at-1-on-Billboard-Chart | archivedate=June 11, 2013 | df=mdy-all }} making it the highest charting Broadway cast recording since ''The Book of Mormon''{{'}}s album was released two years earlier.{{cite web | url=http://top40-charts.com/news/Movies/Kinky-Boots-Debuts-At-No-1-On-Billboard-Cast-Album-Chart/90721.html | title=''Kinky Boots'' Debuts At No 1 On Billboard Cast Album Chart | publisher=Top 40 Charts | work=top40-charts.com | date=June 7, 2013 | accessdate=June 7, 2013}} Before the Chicago tryout, "Sex Is in the Heel" became the first Broadway song to reach the top 10 of the [[Hot Dance Club Songs|''Billboard'' club charts]] in 25 years. "Land of Lola" was released as a dance remix by Wayne G. & LFB in June 2013.{{cite web| url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/179642-Kinky-Boots-Land-of-Lola-With-Billy-Porter-Released-as-Dance-Remix| title=''Kinky Boots''{{'}} "Land of Lola," With Billy Porter, Released as Dance Remix| work=[[Playbill]]| accessdate=November 7, 2013| date=June 28, 2013| author=Hetrick, Adam| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109113055/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/179642-Kinky-Boots-Land-of-Lola-With-Billy-Porter-Released-as-Dance-Remix| archivedate=November 9, 2013| df=mdy-all}} The album received a favorable review in ''[[Playbill]]'' from Steven Suskin{{cite web| url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/180700-ON-THE-RECORD-The-New-Broadway-Cast-Album-of-Kinky-Boots-and-Audra-McDonalds-Go-Back-Home| title=On the Record: The New Broadway Cast Album of ''Kinky Boots'' and Audra McDonald's "Go Back Home"| accessdate=November 7, 2013| date=August 4, 2013| author=Suskin, Steven| work=[[Playbill]]| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203002347/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/180700-ON-THE-RECORD-The-New-Broadway-Cast-Album-of-Kinky-Boots-and-Audra-McDonalds-Go-Back-Home| archivedate=December 3, 2013| df=mdy-all}} and won the [[Grammy Award for Best Musical Theater Album]].{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/186925-Kinky-Boots-Wins-Grammy-Award-for-Best-Musical-Theater-Album?tsrc=hph|title=''Kinky Boots'' Wins Grammy Award for Best Musical Theater Album|accessdate=January 27, 2014|date=January 26, 2014|work=[[Playbill]]|author=Hetrick, Adam|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201175328/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/186925-Kinky-Boots-Wins-Grammy-Award-for-Best-Musical-Theater-Album?tsrc=hph|archivedate=February 1, 2014|df=mdy-all}} A West End Original Cast Recording was recorded live at the Adelphi Theatre and released April 1, 2016.{{cite web | url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/london-theatre/news/kinky-boots-release-west-end-cast-recording_39892.html | title=Kinky Boots to release West End cast recording | publisher=[[What's On Stage]] | work=whatsonstage.com | date=March 4, 2016 | accessdate=March 11, 2016}} The West End cast recording was nominated for a 2017 [[Grammy Award for Best Musical Theater Album]].Viagas, Robert. [http://www.playbill.com/article/waitress-and-bright-star-cast-albums-among-grammy-award-nominees# " 'Waitress' and 'Bright Star' Cast Albums Among Grammy Award Nominees"] Playbill, December 6, 2016 ==Collaboration== In summer 2018, a Kinky Boots co-branded pop-up store launched at [[Mellower Coffee]]'s Tongren Road location in Shanghai. Mellower Coffee has specially made a "Sparkle Dance" drink for this event.{{cite web |title=The co-branded pop-up store of Kinky Boots and Mellower Coffee has come to the end, Mellower comprehensively promotes brand globalization strategy|url=http://www.providenceheadlines.com/story/180530/the-cobranded-popup-store-of-kinky-boots-and-mellower-coffee-has-come-to-the-endmellower-comprehensively-promotes-brand-globalization-strategy.html|website=providenceheadlines.com|accessdate=August 14, 2018}} ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.kinkybootsthemusical.com/ Official website] *[http://www.ibdb.com/show.php?id=493286 Kinky Boots] at [[IBDb]] *[http://www.playbillvault.com/Show/Detail/13982/Kinky-Boots ''Kinky Boots''] at Playbill Vault *[http://www.theatermania.com/chicago-theater/shows/kinky-boots_192670/ ''Kinky Boots''] at Theater Mania *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130512062209/http://www.tonyawards.com/en_US/news/articles/2013-03-22/201303231364001129565.html ''Kinky Boots''] at [[Tony Awards]].com {{Cyndi Lauper}} {{Navboxes | title = Awards for ''Kinky Boots'' | list = {{OlivierAward Musical 2001–2025}} {{TonyAward Musical 2001–2025}} {{TonyAward MusicalScore 2001–2025}} }} [[Category:2012 musicals]] [[Category:Broadway musicals]] [[Category:LGBT-related musicals]] [[Category:Musicals based on films]] [[Category:Musicals inspired by real-life events]] [[Category:Cyndi Lauper]] [[Category:Rock musicals]] [[Category:Tony Award for Best Musical]] [[Category:Child characters in musical theatre]]

Adding local [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "The condition of a taxon ceasing to exist in a region which it previously inhabited" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|The condition of a taxon ceasing to exist in a region which it previously inhabited}} {{refimprove|date=August 2017}}{{Redirect|Extirpation|the surgical term referring to removal of solid matter from the body|[[thrombectomy]], [[endarterectomy]], or [[choledocholithotomy]]}}
'''Local extinction''' or '''extirpation''' is the condition of a [[species]] (or other [[taxon]]) that ceases to exist in the chosen geographic area of study, though it still exists elsewhere.<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Ladle|editor1-first=Richard |editor2-first=Robert J. |editor2-last=Whittaker|title=Conservation Biogeography|date=2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9781444398113|page=61}}</ref> Local [[extinction]]s are contrasted with global extinctions.
Local extinctions may be followed by a replacement of the species taken from other locations; [[wolf reintroduction]] is an example of this.
== Conservation ==
Local extinctions mark a change in the [[ecology]] of an area.
The area of study chosen may reflect a natural subpopulation, political boundaries, or both. The Cetacean Specialist Group of the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature|IUCN]] has assessed the threat of a local extinction of the [[Black Sea]] stock of [[Harbour Porpoise]] (''Phocoena phocoena'') that touches six different countries. [[COSEWIC]], by contrast, investigates wildlife only in Canada, so assesses only the risk of a Canadian local extinction even for species that cross into the United States or other countries. Other subpopulations may be naturally divided by political or country boundaries.
Many crocodilian species have experienced localized extinction, particularly the [[saltwater crocodile]] (''Crocodylus porosus''), which has been extirpated from Vietnam, Thailand, Java, and many other areas.
Often a subpopulation of a species will also be a [[subspecies]]. For example, the recent disappearance of the [[Black Rhinoceros]] (''Diceros bicornis'') from [[Cameroon]] spells not only the local extinction of rhinoceroses in Cameroon, but also the global extinction of the [[Western Black Rhinoceros]] (''Diceros bicornis longipes'').
In at least one case, scientists have found a local extinction useful for research: In the case of the [[Bay checkerspot butterfly]], scientists, including [[Paul R. Ehrlich]], chose not to intervene in a local extinction, using it to study the danger to the world population.<ref name="Holsinger">Holsinger, Kent. "[http://darwin.eeb.uconn.edu/eeb310/lecture-notes/checkerspot/node4.html Local extinction] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311042359/http://darwin.eeb.uconn.edu/eeb310/lecture-notes/checkerspot/node4.html |date=2007-03-11 }}". ''Population Viability Analysis: Bay Checkerspot Butterfly''. URL accessed August 11, 2006.</ref> However, similar studies are not carried out where a global population is at risk.
== IUCN subpopulation and stock assessments == While the [[World Conservation Union]] (IUCN) mostly only categorizes whole species or subspecies, assessing the global risk of extinction, in some cases it also assesses the risks to stocks and populations, especially to preserve genetic diversity. In all, 119 stocks or subpopulations across 69 species have been assessed by the IUCN in 2006.<ref>[[IUCN Red List]], search for only stocks and subpopulations [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/search.php?freetext=&modifier=phrase&criteria=wholedb&taxa_stock=1&Submit.x=0&Submit.y=0&redlistCategory%5B%5D=all&redlistAssessyear%5B%5D=all&country%5B%5D=all&aquatic%5B%5D=all&regions%5B%5D=all&habitats%5B%5D=all&threats%5B%5D=all]{{Dead link|date=August 2017}}</ref>
Examples of stocks and populations assessed by the IUCN for the threat of local extinction: * [[Marsh deer]] (three subpopulations assessed) * [[Blue whale]], North Pacific stock and North Atlantic stock * [[Bowhead whale]], ''Balaena mysticetus'' (five subpopulations assessed), from Critically Endangered to [[LR/cd]] * [[Lake sturgeon]], ''Acipenser fulvescens'', Mississippi & Missouri Basins subpopulation assessed as [[Vulnerable species|Vulnerable]] * Wild [[common carp]], ''Cyprinus carpio'' (River Danube subpopulation) * [[Black-flanked rock-wallaby]] ''Petrogale lateralis'' (MacDonnell Ranges subpopulation and Western Kimberly subpopulation)
The IUCN also lists countries where assessed species, subspecies or subpopulations are found, and from which countries they have been extirpated or reintroduced.
The IUCN has only three entries for subpopulations that have become extinct<ref>[[IUCN Red List]], search for extinct stocks and populations: [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/search.php?freetext=&modifier=phrase&criteria=wholedb&taxa_stock=1&Submit.x=0&Submit.y=0&redlistCategory%5B%5D=EX&redlistCategory%5B%5D=EW&redlistAssessyear%5B%5D=all&country%5B%5D=all&aquatic%5B%5D=all&regions%5B%5D=all&habitats%5B%5D=all&threats%5B%5D=all]{{Dead link|date=August 2017}}</ref>the [[Aral Sea]] stock of [[Ship sturgeon]] (''Acipenser nudiventris''); the [[Adriatic Sea]] stock of [[Beluga sturgeon|Beluga]] (''Huso huso''); and the [[Mexican wolf|Mexican]] subpopulation of [[Wolf]] (''Canis lupus''), which is extinct in the wild. No plant or fungi subpopulations have been assessed by the IUCN.
== Local extinction events ==
Major environmental events, such as volcanic eruptions, may lead to large numbers of local extinctions, such as with the [[1980 Mount St. Helens eruption]], which led to a [[fern spike]] extinction.

[[File:Taisten-Tabernakelbildstock 04.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Christ on the Mount of Olives]] '''Christ's agony at Gethsemane''' is a passage in the [[Gospel of Luke]] (22:43–44), describing a prayer of [[Jesus]], after which he receives strength from an angel, on the Mount of Olives prior to his betrayal and arrest. It is one of several passages which appear in most versions of the [[New Testament]], but are absent in earlier manuscripts. The situation of Jesus, prior to the completion of his ministry, begging weakness to God to perform the difficult task has been compared to [[Book of Exodus|Exodus 3]], wherein the prophet [[Moses]] speaks to God and pleads weakness when told to confront Pharaoh.Busse, Heribert. "Islam, Judaism and Christianity: Theological and Historical Affiliations", 1998. p. 126. The authenticity of the passage has been disputed by scholars since the second half of the 19th century. The verses are placed in double brackets in modern editions of the Greek text, and in a footnote in the [[Revised Standard Version|RSV]]. == Text == ::'''Greek '''
ὤφθη δὲ αὐτῷ ἄγγελος ἀπ' οὐρανοῦ ἐνισχύων αὐτὸν. καὶ γενόμενος ἐν ἀγωνίᾳ ἐκτενέστερον προσηύχετο. ἐγένετο δὲ ὁ ἱδρὼς αὐτοῦ ὡσεὶ θρόμβοι αἵματος καταβαίνοντες ἐπὶ τὴν γῆν. ''Ōphthē de autō angelos ap' [[ouranos|ouranou]] enischyōn auton. Kai genomenos en agōnia ektenesteron prosēucheto. Egeneto de ho hidrōs autou hōsei thromboi aimatos katabainontes epi tēn gēn.''
::'''Translation (RSV) '''
And there appeared to him an angel from heaven, strengthening him. And being in an agony he prayed more earnestly; and his [[Hematidrosis|sweat became like great drops of blood]] falling down upon the ground.

[[Theodore of Mopsuestia]] wrote: "When our Lord was in deep thought and fear at the approach of His Passion, the blessed Luke said that 'an angel appeared to Him strengthening and encouraging Him,'"(Comm. on Lord's Prayer, Baptism and Eucharist; Ch. 5) ; Exclude passage Clement, [[Origen]]. == Modern scholars == ; Critical editions UBS4 marks this variant with double square-brackets and the evaluation letter C. ; Individuals [[Thomas Hartwell Horne]] (1856): "the reason for the omission of these verses in some manuscripts and for their being marked as suspected in others, is by some supposed to have been that they were rejected by some of the more timid, lest they should appear to favour the Arians: it may be that they were omitted in Luke from their being early read in a lesson containing part of Matt. C. Burkitt, ''The Old Latin and the Itala'', p. 47 According to [[Herman C. Hoskier]] it can be result of the influence of the [[Docetism|docetics]] of Alexandria.H. C. Hoskier, ''Codex B and its Allies'' (London 1914), vol. 1, p. 408 [[Joel B. Green]] and Scott McKnight (1992) wrote in ''The Dictionary of Jesus and the Gospels'', "Others, however, observe the impressive Lukan character of these verses, which speaks for their originality to the Third Gospel. In addition to (1) the inclusion of characteristic Lukan vocabulary (Green 1988, 56–57), one may also observe (2) the Lukan emphasis on the appearance of an angel (e.g., 1:11, 26; 2:13, 15; Acts 5:19; 7:30; 8:26; 10:3; 12:7), (3) Luke’s interest in simile (“his sweat was like drops of blood,” v. 44; cf. e.g., 3:22; 10:18; 11:44; 22:31) and (4) Luke’s fondness for physical manifestations (like sweat) accompanying extramundane events (e.g., 1:20; 3:22; Acts 2:2–3; 9:18). These data, along with the fact that the presence of these verses is of a piece with Luke’s interpretation of this scene as a whole, point clearly to the originality of 22:43–44. Moreover, it is not difficult to imagine a rationale for the early exclusion of these verses in the manuscript tradition. The portrait of Jesus contained therein—human, agonizing, needful, requiring angelic support—would have been problematic to some (cf. Gos. Nic. 20; Green 1988, 56). Accordingly, they may have been dropped for doctrinal reasons. There is thus good reason for taking these verses as original to Luke." p.266-67 Green, J. B., McKnight, S., & Marshall, I. H. (1992). Dictionary of Jesus and the Gospels [[Kurt Aland]] (1995): "These verses exhibit a conclusive clue to their secondary nature (like the Pericope Adulterae) in the alternative locations for its insertion. While the majority of the (now known) manuscripts place them at Luke 22:43-44, they are found after Matthew 26:39 in the minuscule family 13 and in several lectionaries. This kind fluctuation in the New Testament manuscript tradition is one of the surest evidences for the secondary character of a text."{{Cite book | last = Aland | first = Kurt | authorlink = Kurt Aland | last2 = Aland | first2 = Barbara | authorlink2 = Barbara Aland | others = Erroll F. Rhodes (trans.) | title = The Text of the New Testament: An Introduction to the Critical Editions and to the Theory and Practice of Modern Textual Criticism | publisher = [[William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company]] | year = 1995 | location = Grand Rapids | page = 310 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-8028-4098-1}} [[Bruce M. Metzger]] (2005): "These verses are absent from some of the oldest and best witnesses, including the majority of the Alexandrian manuscripts. It is striking to note that the earliest witnesses attesting the verses are three Church fathers – Justin, Irenaeus, and Hippolytus – each of whom uses the verses in order to counter Christological views that maintained that Jesus was not a full human who experienced the full range of human sufferings. It may well be that the verses were added to the text for just this reason, in opposition to those who held to a docetic Christology".Bruce M. Metzger, ''The Text of the New Testament: Its Transmission, Corruption, and Restoration'' ([[Oxford University Press]]: 2005), p. 286. According to [[Bart D. Ehrman]] (1993) these two verses disrupt the literary structure of the scene (the [[chiasmus]]), they are not found in the early and valuable manuscripts, and they are the only place in Luke where Jesus is seen to be in agony. Ehrman concludes that they were inserted in order to counter [[doceticism]], the belief that Jesus, as divine, only ''seemed'' to suffer. While probably not original to the text, these verses reflect first-century tradition.Bart D. If an entry gets 10% of the tele-votes it will be equivalent to 10% of 473 points. |entries = 32: 8 in each semi-final; 10 in the final (2 from each semi-final, 2 from the Second Chance round) |opening = |interval = }} '''Melodifestivalen 2011''' was a [[Sweden|Swedish]] song contest held between February and March 2011. It selected Sweden's 51st song to represent [[Sweden in the Eurovision Song Contest]], and was the 50th edition of [[Melodifestivalen]]. [[Eric Saade]], with the song "[[Popular (Eric Saade song)|Popular]]", won the contest and thus was selected to represent Sweden in the [[2011 Eurovision Song Contest]]. == Format == The 2011 edition of Melodifestivalen was similar to the previous year's arrangement, with four semi-finals, a second-chance round and a grand final. The four semi-finals were held in [[Luleå]] (5 February), [[Gothenburg]] (12 February), Linköping (19 February) and [[Malmö]] (26 February). The second chance round was held in [[Sundsvall]] on 5 March and the final in Stockholm was held on 12 March.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/15994|title=Changes in Melodifestivalen 2011 announced|last=Yalcinkaya|first=Hakan|date=9 July 2010|publisher=''ESCToday''|accessdate=2010-07-10}}{{cite web|last=Juhas |first=Ervin |title=Sweden: Rules of Melodifestivalen 2011 |url=http://escdaily.com/articles/2387 |publisher=''ESCDaily'' |accessdate=12 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100714021951/http://escdaily.com/articles/2387 |archivedate=14 July 2010 |df= }} SVT presented the competing songs during autumn 2010. As in 2010 and 2009, a maximum of eight people were allowed on stage, while only persons of 16 years or over would be eligible. (However, in accordance with Eurovision rules, only six people were allowed on stage for the Swedish entry at Eurovision.) The main singer(s) had to perform vocals live on stage, however other backing vocals could be pre-recorded along with the song's backing track. There was a large change in the way that the 32 songs were selected. In 2010, 27 songs were selected by a selection panel, 4 songs were then selected by SVT in order to diversify the musical quality of the contest and one song was then selected through a "Web wildcard" competition. Members of the public were allowed to submit songs onto the SVT website, with the public selecting one song through SMS voting. For 2011, this was changed: only 15 songs were selected by the selection panel. The remaining 15 songs were then selected by SVT, from remaining submissions made to the selection panel, or from specially invited artists and songs. The web wildcard competition was expanded; instead of just one song was chosen, the public selected two songs. The web wildcard competition began on 11 October, and ended with a live show on 8 November on [[SVT24]], held at the ''Golden Hits nightclub'' in Stockholm.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=19993&_t=Swedish+web+jokers+to+go+on+TV|title=Swedish web jokers to go on TV|last=Siim|first=Jarmo|date=9 September 2010|publisher=''Eurovision.tv''|accessdate=2010-09-09}}{{cite web|last=Klier |first=Marcus |title=Sweden: Televised web joker selection on 8th November |url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/16107 |publisher=''ESCToday'' |accessdate=9 September 2010 |date=9 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100911050743/http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/16107 |archivedate=11 September 2010 |df= }}{{cite web|last=Brunell |first=Lilian |title=Golden Hits hosts the wildcard selection |url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=9067 |publisher=''Oikotimes'' |accessdate=2 November 2010 |date=2 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101229231302/http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=9067 |archivedate=29 December 2010 |df= }} Other changes introduced to Melodifestivalen 2011 were revealed by SVT. For the first time, non-Swedish [[songwriter]]s were able to enter songs into the contest, as long as there is at least one Swedish songwriter also contributing. Solo singer-instrumentalists were now allowed to perform their instruments live during the TV broadcast. On 17 November, SVT announced [[Marie Serneholt]] and [[Rickard Olsson]] as the hosts for the semi-finals, the second chance and the final, but there was also a guest host in each program.{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.121594/1.2237287/marie_serneholt_och_rickard_olsson_leder_melodifestivalen_2011?lid=puff_2237276&lpos=lasMer |title=Marie Serneholt och Rickard Olsson leder Melodifestivalen 2011 |date=17 November 2010 |publisher=''SVT'' |accessdate=17 November 2010 |language=Swedish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612234504/http://svt.se/2.121594/1.2237287/marie_serneholt_och_rickard_olsson_leder_melodifestivalen_2011?lid=puff_2237276&lpos=lasMer |archivedate=12 June 2011 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/16240|title=Marie Serneholt and Rickard Olsson host Melodifestivalen 2011|last=Repo|first=Juha|date=17 November 2010|publisher=''ESCToday''|accessdate=17 November 2010}} === Changes === Reference:{{cite web|url=http://poplight.zitiz.se/artikel/sa-blir-nya-melodifestivalen|title=Så blir nya Melodifestivalen |date=9 July 2010|publisher=''Poplight''|accessdate=9 July 2010|language=Swedish}} * All entries were submitted via Melodifestivalen website instead of by post. * The selection panel and SVT chose fifteen entries each, instead of the selection panel choosing twenty-seven and SVT four. * Foreign songwriters could post entries, but only in combination with at least one Swedish author. * Artists were able to play at least one instrument live on stage. * In the regular selection process, it was the only established songwriters who could submit entries. The public were only allowed to submit entries to the web wildcard competition. * As in previous years, the songs may be up to three minutes on stage, but a new rule is that they must be at least two minutes long. * The whole voting in the final will be changed. The total value of the votes are 946 points, which means that tele-votes and jury-votes represent 50/50 each. If an entry is getting 10% of the tele-votes it will be equivalent to 47 points. The Swedish jury groups are replaced by 11 international groups. Each jury group gives their points according to the ESC-standard: 1, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 and 12 points. If two songs end up at the same position, the people’s votes will overrule the jury-votes. ==Schedule== [[File:Nanne Grönvall at Melodifestivalen 2011.jpg|thumb|right|Rickard Olsson, [[Nanne Grönvall]] and [[Marie Serneholt]] during the first semi-final broadcast]] {| class="wikitable" |- ! The format for the contest remained the same from last year's, the same format that was introduced in 2002. The 32 songs were presented over 4 semi-finals. A public televote was held to select two songs to progress directly to the final, with the 3rd and 4th placed songs progressing to a Second Chance (''Andra Chansen'') round. The eight songs in the Second Chance round battled in duels until two songs are left, which also progress to the final. In the final, the votes of the public constituted 50% of the total vote, with the remaining 50% coming from the juries. On 22 September, SVT announced that a record number of 3852 entries have been submitted. 424 of them were submitted to the web wildcard selection.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/16142 |title=Sweden: Record numbers entering Melodifestivalen |last=Hondal |first=Victor |date=22 September 2010 |publisher=''Esctoday.com'' |accessdate=2010-09-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100925235105/http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/16142 |archivedate=25 September 2010 |df= }} === Web wildcards === From July to November 2010 SVT held the second Melodifestivalen web wildcard contest. From 9 July to 21 September musicians with no previous music contract could submit songs to the SVT Melodifestivalen website. From 11 October the 232 submissions could be voted on by SMS voting, with only five being left to progress to the web wildcard final on 8 November. Of the 424 entries entered into the contest, 232 were selected to compete after disqualifying those that did not meet the rules of the contest. * 11 October 2010 - all 232 entries were made available for voting * 18 October 2010 - 100 entries went on to the next round * 25 October 2010 - 50 entries went on to the next round * 27 October 2010 - 20 entries went on to the next round (the votes were now reset for the remaining songs) * 29 October 2010 - 15 entries went on to the next round * 31 October 2010 - 10 entries went on to the next round * 1–5 November 2010 - ten entries left, one song voted out every day * 8 November 2010 - five entries remained in the web wildcard final, where two songs were selected to compete in the Melodifestivalen semi-finals On 31 October the top ten songs were announced by SVT. The jury, which chose the fifteen songs of the over 3000 submissions, were selected at the end of September 2010. SVT's fifteen wild cards and the jury's choice has and will be revealed before the end of November 2010. The two web wildcards were chosen by viewers on 8 November 2010. SVT announced the first four songs on 7 October, which featured the return of three-time competitor [[Linda Bengtzing]].{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=20423&_t=First+four+entries+for+Sweden+announced|title=First four entries for Sweden announced|last=Siim|first=Jarmo|date=7 October 2010|publisher=''Eurovision.tv''|accessdate=2010-10-07}}{{cite web|last=Hondal|first=Victor|title=Sweden: First names entering MF 2011 known|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/16166|publisher=''ESCToday''|accessdate=7 October 2010|date=7 October 2010}}{{cite web|title=De fyra första bidragen och artisterna är klara för Melodifestivalen 2011|url=http://svt.se/2.121594/1.2182352/de_fyra_forsta_bidragen_och_artisterna_ar_klara_for_melodifestivalen_2011&from=rss|publisher=''[[Sveriges Television]]''|accessdate=9 October 2010|language=Swedish|date=9 October 2010}} A further eight songs were announced on 19 October, with [[Sanna Nielsen]] and [[Danny Saucedo|Danny]] returning.{{cite web|title=Åtta nya bidrag och artister klara för Melodifestivalen 2011|url=http://svt.se/2.121594/1.2198830/atta_nya_bidrag_och_artister_klara_for_melodifestivalen_2011&from=rss|publisher=''[[Sveriges Television]]''|accessdate=19 October 2010|language=Swedish|date=19 October 2010}}{{cite web|last=Viniker |first=Barry |title=Eight more Melodifestivalen acts announced |url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/16177 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101023054846/http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/16177 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=23 October 2010 |publisher=''ESCToday'' |accessdate=19 October 2010 |date=19 October 2010 }} The 13th song in Melodifestivalen 2011 was revealed on 1 November: [[Lars-Åke Wilhelmsson]], aka Babsan, will compete with "Ge mig en spanjor",{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.121594/1.2220061/babsan_klar_for_melodifestivalen_2011?lid=puff_2220012&lpos=lasMer |title=Babsan klar för Melodifestivalen 2011! |publisher=''[[Sveriges Television]]'' |accessdate=2010-11-01 |language=Swedish |date=1 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612162214/http://svt.se/2.121594/1.2220061/babsan_klar_for_melodifestivalen_2011?lid=puff_2220012&lpos=lasMer |archivedate=12 June 2011 |df= }}{{cite web|last=Hondal|first=Victor|title=Babsan enters Melodifestivalen 2011|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/16198|publisher=''ESCToday''|accessdate=1 November 2010|date=1 November 2010}} and on 3 November SVT revealed that [[Nicke Borg]] will also compete in the contest with the song "Leaving Home".{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.121594/1.2222758/nicke_borg_klar_for_melodifestivalen_2011?lid=puff_2222763&lpos=lasMer |title=Nicke Borg klar för Melodifestivalen 2011! |date=3 November 2010 |publisher=''SVT'' |accessdate=2010-11-03 |language=Swedish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612162226/http://svt.se/2.121594/1.2222758/nicke_borg_klar_for_melodifestivalen_2011?lid=puff_2222763&lpos=lasMer |archivedate=12 June 2011 |df= }} On 7 November it was revealed by [[Expressen]] that former Eurovision Song Contest winner [[Elisabeth Andreassen]] would make a return to Melodifestivalen in 2011. Andreassen won the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1985|1985 Eurovision]] for [[Norway]] as part of [[Bobbysocks!]], and also took part in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1994|1994]] (with [[Jan Werner Danielsen]]). She also competed for Norway in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1996|1996]], and in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1982|1982]] for Sweden (as part of [[Chips (band)|Chips]]).{{cite web|last=Brännström|first=Linus|title=Elisabeth Andreassen klar för Melodifestivalen|url=http://www.expressen.se/noje/musik/1.2204379/elisabeth-andreassen-klar-for-melodifestivalen|publisher=''[[Expressen]]''|accessdate=7 November 2010|language=Swedish|date=7 November 2010}} On 8 November SVT confirmed that Andreassen would make a comeback to Melodifestivalen, and will take part with the song "Vaken i en dröm".{{cite web|title=Elisabeth Andreassen är klar för Melodifestivalen 2011! |url=http://svt.se/2.121594/1.2227406/elisabeth_andreassen_ar_klar_for_melodifestivalen_2011?lid=puff_2225591&lpos=lasMer |publisher=''[[Sveriges Television]]'' |accessdate=8 November 2010 |language=Swedish |date=8 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612162243/http://svt.se/2.121594/1.2227406/elisabeth_andreassen_ar_klar_for_melodifestivalen_2011?lid=puff_2225591&lpos=lasMer |archivedate=12 June 2011 |df= }} Also on 8 November the web wildcard contest ended with a live TV final on [[SVT24]]. [[Julia Alvgard]] and [[Jonas Matsson]] won after the public televote with the songs "Better or Worse" and "On My Own".{{cite web|last=Yalcinkaya |first=Hakan |title=Three more acts for Melodifestivalen 2011 |url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/16223 |publisher=''ESCToday'' |accessdate=8 November 2010 |date=8 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101112005416/http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/16223 |archivedate=12 November 2010 |df= }}{{cite web|last=Dahlander|first=Gustav|title=From the Web to the Swedish Eurovision selections|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=20863&_t=From+the+Web+to+the+Swedish+Eurovision+selections|publisher=''[[European Broadcasting Union]]''|accessdate=9 November 2010|date=9 November 2010}} On 22 November, a further six entries were revealed by SVT. However, during this press conference SVT revealed the entries that would compete in the first two semi-finals.{{cite web|title=Melodifestivalen 2011: Brolle, Le Kid och Christian Walz bland 2011 års artister|url=http://poplight.zitiz.se/artikel/melodifestivalen-2011-brolle-le-kid-och-christian-walz-bland-2011-ars-artister|publisher=''Poplight''|accessdate=22 November 2010|language=Swedish|date=22 November 2010}} The remaining entries were announced on a press conferences on 29 November, which featured the return of [[Shirley Clamp]] and [[Eric Saade]].{{cite web|title=Melodifestivalen 2011: Shirley Clamp och Eric Saade bland artisterna|url=http://poplight.zitiz.se/artikel/melodifestivalen-2011-shirley-clamp-och-eric-saade-bland-artisterna|publisher=''Poplight''|accessdate=29 November 2010|language=Swedish|date=29 November 2010}} However, on 27 November, [[Christer Björkman]] revealed the Swedish dance band [[The Playtones]] would participate in Melodifestivalen 2011 with the song "[[The King (The Playtones song)|The King]]".{{cite web|title=The Playtones klara för Melodifestivalen 2011|url=http://poplight.zitiz.se/artikel/playtones-klara-foer-melodifestivalen-2011|publisher=''Poplight''|accessdate=27 November 2010|language=Swedish|date=27 November 2010}} The song "Don't Stop" was disqualified because it has been published on Chasez [[MySpace]]. However, SVT told the songwriters and the artist [[Andreas Fernette]] to write a new song.{{cite web|title=Låt diskas i Melodifestivalen|url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/nojesbladet/melodifestivalen2011/article8197773.ab|publisher=''Aftonbladet''|accessdate=29 November 2010|language=Swedish|date=29 November 2010}} On 10 December, SVT announced Fernette's new song "Run".{{cite web|title=Det nya bidraget heter "Run" |url=http://svt.se/2.121594/1.2264432/det_nya_bidraget_heter_run?lid=puff_2264425&lpos=lasMer |accessdate=10 December 2010 |language=Swedish |date=10 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110221132813/http://svt.se/2.121594/1.2264432/det_nya_bidraget_heter_run?lid=puff_2264425&lpos=lasMer |archivedate=21 February 2011 |df= }} On 5 January 2011, SVT revealed [[Love Generation (group)|Love Generation]]'s song "Dance Alone" and the running order for each semi-final.{{cite web|title=Sweden: Running order for MF 2011 announced |url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/16436 |publisher=''ESCToday'' |accessdate=5 January 2011 |date=5 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110107092248/http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/16436 |archivedate=7 January 2011 |df= }} SVT announced that this years Melodifestivalen would have the same rules in the semi-finals as there were in [[Melodifestivalen 2010]]. This means that the song which receiving the most votes in the first round would automatically qualify to the final, skipping the second round. The remaining top four would battle again for a place in the final and ''Andra Chansen'' round - the 2nd placed song qualifying to the final, the 3rd and 4th placed songs progressing to Andra Chansen, and the song places fifth will be eliminated from the competition. However, SVT will not announce the vote result for each song until the final has been broadcast. === Semi-final 1 === The first semi-final was held on 5 February 2011 in [[Coop Norrbotten Arena]], [[Luleå]]. During the show, the on-screen graphics displayed the wrong phone numbers on the Radiohjälpen number during Duels 1, 2 and 3. border-style: solid;border-color:black;"|  |- | height=6| |} == Final == The final of Melodifestivalen 2011 was held on 12 March 2011 at the Globe Arena in Stockholm. The two winners from each of the four semi-finals and the two ''Second chance'' winners qualified for the final, A total of 10 songs. The winner was decided by a mix of televoting/SMS voting and jury voting. On 17 December 2010, Swedish newspaper ''[[Expressen]]'' announced that SVT planned to change the voting system in the Melodifestivalen Final.{{cite web|title=Folket förlorar makten i Melodifestivalen|url=http://www.expressen.se/noje/musik/1.2258372/folket-forlorar-makten-i-melodifestivalen|publisher=''Expressen''|accessdate=17 December 2010|language=Swedish|date=17 December 2010}} On 10 January 2011, SVT gave details about that. The value of the votes was 946 points, which meant that tele-votes and jury-votes represent 50/50 each. If an entry is getting 10% of the tele-votes, it would be equivalent to 47 points. The Swedish jury groups were replaced by eleven international groups. Each jury group gave their points as follows: 1, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 and 12 points. If two songs end up at the same position, the people’s votes would overrule the jury-votes.{{cite web|title=SWEDEN New voting rules in Melodifestivalen 2011 |url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=9555 |publisher=''Oikotimes.com'' |accessdate=10 January 2011 |date=10 January 2011 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The running order for the Final was made immediately after the Second Chance round. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" |- !rowspan="2"|Draw !rowspan="2"|Artist !rowspan="2"|Song

'''''Mortal Kombat: Live Tour''''' was a [[martial art]] [[theatre|theatrical]] stage show featuring ''[[Mortal Kombat]]'' characters, sound, and [[Laser lighting display|laser light effects]] on stage. The plot was based on three fighters rescuing their friends and retrieving a magic [[amulet]] from the evil master of Outworld, [[Shao Kahn]], in order to save the Earth.
The show debuted at [[Radio City Music Hall]] in [[New York City]] on September 14, 1995, followed by a 200 city road trip into 1996. It replicated ''Mortal Kombat'' [[martial arts]] and [[video game]] moves on stage mixed with dancing and music. [[Lip synching]] were pre-recorded and used to demonstrate the official ''MK'' [[sound effects]], though there was no graphic violence or [[Fatality (Mortal Kombat)|Fatalities]] visible in the show. The audience participated by yelling "Run!" or "Kick him!" as part of the live action.

[[File:Richard Launcelot Maury.jpg|thumb|Richard Launcelot Maury, who developed the idea for the New Virginia Colony.]] The '''New Virginia Colony''' was a colonization plan in central [[Mexico]], to resettle ex-[[Confederate States of America|Confederates]]<ref>Among those who "fled" to Mexico to save their lives from a revengeful Northern administration was [[Pendleton Murrah]], the recently-elected governor of Texas.</ref> after the [[American Civil War]]. The largest settlement was Carlota, approximately midway between [[Mexico City]] and [[Veracruz (city)|Veracruz]], although other settlements were planned near [[Tampico]], [[Monterrey]], [[Cuernavaca]], and [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]].<ref>Andew Rolle, ''The Lost Cause: The Confederate Exodus to Mexico'' (University of Oklahoma Press, 1965). {{ISBN|978-0-8061-1961-8}} (reprint, 1992).</ref>
The venture was conceived by Commodore [[Matthew Fontaine Maury]]. Because of his work for the [[Confederate Secret Service]], Maury was unable to return home to [[Virginia]].<ref>Charles Lee Lewis, ''Matthew Fontaine Maury: The Pathfinder of the Seas'' (U.S. Naval Institute, 1927). {{ISBN|1-4366-7917-6}} (reprint, Kessinger Publishing, 2008).</ref> Maury, as an internationally famous [[oceanographer]] and navy man, was a long-time friend of Emperor [[Maximilian I of Mexico|Maximilian]] of Mexico and had been awarded a medal by Maximilian before the Civil War. Maximilian had also been head of the [[Austrian Navy]] and awarded Maury the medal for his work in oceanography.
Maximilian liked Maury and his idea of inviting Confederates and anyone else to resettle in Mexico and offered land grants to any who would come and stay. Slavery was banned in Mexican law however, so no settler could bring slaves into Mexico. He was also eagerly seeking settlers from [[Germany]], [[Austria]], and [[France]], as part of his strategy to rebuild and Europeanize Mexico.<ref>Jasper Ridley, ''Maximilian and Juarez'' (Ticknor & Fields, 1992). {{ISBN|1-84212-150-2}} (reprint, Phoenix Press, 2001).</ref>
Maury explained a network of planned settlements to Maximilian, who liked what was heard. They were to be primarily in the agricultural regions surrounding Mexico City but also in the northern areas around Monterrey and Chihuahua. American "colonization agents" were appointed to districts, and Maury began to prepare surveys for the proposed colonies. One of Maury's colleagues was explorer and archeologist [[William Marshall Anderson]], whose brother, U.S. Brevet Major General [[Robert Anderson (Civil War)|Robert Anderson]], had commanded the Union soldiers at [[Fort Sumter]]. Two others had worked under Maury when he was the superintendent of the [[U.S. Naval Observatory]]. His eldest son, Col. Richard Launcelot Maury, had also emigrated to Mexico. Maury had plans for his entire family to eventually move there to a colony. Virginia was war-torn: "back to what? To poverty and misery . . ." declared Maury in a September 1865 letter. <ref>{{Cite wikisource | title = Matthew Fontaine Maury, Chapter 15 | last = Fontaine Corbin | first = Diane | year = 1888 }}</ref>
Confederate generals such as Fighting [[Jo Shelby]], [[Edmund Kirby Smith]], [[John B. Magruder]], [[Sterling Price]], [[Thomas C. Hindman]], and [[Alexander W. Terrell]] made their way to Mexico after the war.<ref>Rolle, ''The Lost Cause''. Also see, ''An American in Maximilian's Mexico 1865-1866'' by [[William Marshall Anderson]], who was using the trip as an archeological expedition.</ref>
Throughout the period, Maximilian's regime was under attack by Republican leaders [[Benito Juárez]] and [[Porfirio Díaz]]. From 1865 onward, Juárez and Díaz were covertly supplied from a US Army depot in [[El Paso, Texas]]. In 1866, [[Napoleon III]] withdrew the French troops that had been supporting Maximilian.<ref>Richard O'Connor, ''The Cactus Throne: The Tragedy of Maximilian and Carlotta'' (Putnam, 1971). {{ISBN|0-380-00641-3}} (reprint, Avon, 1976).</ref>
When the French withdrew from Carlota in March 1867, the area was overrun by the forces of Juárez and the remaining New Virginia colonists fled the area. The New Virginia settlements were abandoned as the anti-Maximilian forces reached them. The survivors generally moved toward the coast. The imperial government collapsed in May 1867 and most of the settlers left Mexico.

{{primarysources|date=March 2009}} '''Novinite''' is a [[Bulgaria]]n English-language news provider based in [[Sofia]]. "Novinite" ({{lang-bg|Новините}}) means "The News" in Bulgarian. It is also sometimes referred to as SNA by its forum users.
Through its website novinite.com/sofianewsagency.com and its ''Breaking News'' newsletter, Novinite.com provides coverage of events and developments in Bulgaria and around the world.
Novinite publishes ''Sofia Morning News'', an online daily [[newspaper]] with paid subscription, and ''The Sofia Weekly'', a free online weekly newspaper which comes out every Saturday.
Its website includes a forum, a free archive with more than 101,000 articles, a search engine, and news alerts.
Novinite is part of [[One Click Media Group]].
==History== Novinite was founded in 2001 by the Bulgarian journalist, businessman, and public relations expert, [[Maxim Behar]]. It was formally launched on March 11, 2001.
In addition to the website, Novinite's first online daily newspaper, ''Sofia Morning News'' (called ''Bulgarian Breaking News'' at the time), was launched on June 1, 2001.
==Articles== * On December 21, 2008 Novinite published its 100,000th news article, an average of 35 news articles per day. * The first news article published by Novinite was: "Radisson SAS Opens in Sofia" (March 11, 2001). * Novinite's 10,000th news article was: "Israeli PM Ariel Sharon Won't Allow Ultra-Orthodox Parties to Rejoin Coalition" (May 22, 2002). * Novinite's 50,000th news article was: "King's Party: Saxe-Coburg May Not Head Next Cabinet" (July 14, 2005). * Novinite's 100,000th news article was about Novinite itself: "Novinite.com Becomes Media Partner of Invest in Bulgaria 2009 Business Summit" (December 21, 2008).
==Coverage== The editorial team of Novinite provides news coverage in English of every aspect of contemporary Bulgaria including business and economy, politics, sports, society, culture, and lifestyle. Novinite features headlines covering the major world events and developments.
Novinite uses [[American English]].
==Readership== Novinite's readers include foreign businessmen and managers of multinational corporations doing or planning to do business in Bulgaria, diplomats in foreign embassies in Sofia and from all over the world, foreign citizens living in Bulgaria, foreign tourists, members of the Bulgarian immigrant communities around the world, and Bulgaria lovers.

An '''occupational injury''' is bodily damage resulting from working. The most common [[Organ (anatomy)|organ]]s involved are the [[vertebral column|spine]], [[hand]]s, the [[Human head|head]], [[human lung|lung]]s, [[human eye|eye]]s, [[human skeleton|skeleton]], and [[human skin|skin]]. Occupational injuries can result from exposure to [[occupational hazard]]s ([[Physical hazard|physical]], [[Chemical hazard|chemical]], [[Biological hazard|biological]], or [[Psychosocial hazard|psychosocial]]), such as [[temperature]], [[noise]], [[Insect bites and stings|insect]] or [[animal bite]]s, [[Blood-borne disease|blood-borne pathogens]], [[aerosol]]s, [[Dangerous goods|hazardous chemicals]], [[radiation]], and [[occupational burnout]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/hazards.html|title=Hazards & Exposures|website=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|access-date=2016-07-07}}</ref>
While many prevention methods are set in place, injuries may still occur due to poor [[ergonomics]], [[manual handling]] of heavy loads, misuse or failure of equipment, exposure to general hazards, and inadequate safety training.
==Worldwide== It has been estimated that worldwide there are more than 350,000 workplace fatalities and more than 270 million workplace injuries annually.<ref>Barling, J., & Frone, M. R. (2004). Occupational injuries: Setting the stage. In J. Barling & M. R. Frone (Eds.), The psychology of workplace safety. Washington, DC: APA.</ref> In 2000 there were approximately 2.9 billion workers worldwide. Occupational injuries resulted in the loss of 3.5 years of healthy life for every 1,000 workers.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Concha-Barrientos|first=Marisol|last2=Nelson|first2=Deborah Imel|last3=Fingerhut|first3=Marilyn|last4=Driscoll|first4=Timothy|last5=Leigh|first5=James|date=2005-12-01|title=The global burden due to occupational injury|journal=American Journal of Industrial Medicine|volume=48|issue=6|pages=470–481|doi=10.1002/ajim.20226|issn=0271-3586|pmid=16299709}}</ref> 300,000 of the occupational injuries resulted in a fatality.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Takala|first=Jukka|last2=Hämäläinen|first2=Päivi|last3=Saarela|first3=Kaija Leena|last4=Yun|first4=Loke Yoke|last5=Manickam|first5=Kathiresan|last6=Jin|first6=Tan Wee|last7=Heng|first7=Peggy|last8=Tjong|first8=Caleb|last9=Kheng|first9=Lim Guan|date=2014-01-01|title=Global estimates of the burden of injury and illness at work in 2012|journal=Journal of Occupational and Environmental Hygiene|volume=11|issue=5|pages=326–337|doi=10.1080/15459624.2013.863131|issn=1545-9632|pmc=4003859|pmid=24219404}}</ref>
The most common occupations associated with these hazards vary throughout the world depending on the major industries in a particular country. Overall, the most hazardous occupations are in farming, fishing, and forestry.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=El-Menyar|first=Ayman|last2=Mekkodathil|first2=Ahammed|last3=Al-Thani|first3=Hassan|date=2016-01-01|title=Occupational injuries in workers from different ethnicities|url=http://www.ijciis.org/text.asp?2016/6/1/25/177365|journal=International Journal of Critical Illness and Injury Science|language=en|volume=6|issue=1|doi=10.4103/2229-5151.177365}}</ref> In more developed countries, construction <ref name="Dong 303–315">{{Cite journal|last=Dong|first=Xiuwen Sue|last2=Wang|first2=Xuanwen|last3=Daw|first3=Christina|date=2012-06-01|title=Fatal falls among older construction workers|journal=Human Factors|volume=54|issue=3|pages=303–315|issn=0018-7208|pmid=22768635|doi=10.1177/0018720811410057}}</ref> and manufacturing <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Yu|first=Shanfa|last2=Lu|first2=Ming-Lun|last3=Gu|first3=Guizhen|last4=Zhou|first4=Wenhui|last5=He|first5=Lihua|last6=Wang|first6=Sheng|date=2012-03-01|title=Musculoskeletal symptoms and associated risk factors in a large sample of Chinese workers in Henan province of China|journal=American Journal of Industrial Medicine|volume=55|issue=3|pages=281–293|doi=10.1002/ajim.21037|issn=1097-0274|pmid=22125090}}</ref> occupations are associated with high rates of spine, hand, and wrist injuries.
==By country== ===United States=== In the United States in 2012, 4,383 workers died from job injuries, 92% of which were men,<ref>US Department of Labor, Bureau of Labor Statistics. "Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries Charts, 1992-2012."</ref> and nearly 3 million nonfatal workplace injuries & illness were reported which cost businesses a collective loss of $198.2 billion and 60 million workdays.<ref name="workplace-safety-by-the-numbers">[http://www.prudentialuniforms.com/blog/uniforms-and-apparel/workplace-safety-by-the-numbers Workplace Safety By The Numbers] - "U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics"</ref> In 2007, 5,488 workers died from job injuries, 92% of which were men,<ref>US Department of Labor, Bureau of Labor Statistics.
