Workplace injuries and illnesses in 2007. Washington, DC: US Department of Labor; 2008. Retrieved at: [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/about.html About NIOSH]. Available at [http://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/osh.pdf].</ref>
According to data from the [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health]] (NIOSH) and the [[Bureau of Labor Statistics]], an average of 15 workers die from traumatic injuries each day in the United States, and an additional 200 workers are hospitalized.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/injury/|title=Traumatic Occupational Injuries|publisher=National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|accessdate=29 May 2009}}</ref>
In a study in the state of [[Washington (state)|Washington]], injured workers were followed for 14 years to determine the long term effects of work injury on employment. The work injuries resulted in an average of 1.06 years of lost productivity for each of the 31,588 allowed claims.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fulton-Kehoe|first=D.|last2=Franklin|first2=G.|last3=Weaver|first3=M.|last4=Cheadle|first4=A.|date=2000-06-01|title=Years of productivity lost among injured workers in Washington state: modeling disability burden in workers' compensation|journal=American Journal of Industrial Medicine|volume=37|issue=6|pages=656–662|issn=0271-3586|pmid=10797509|doi=10.1002/(sici)1097-0274(200006)37:6<656::aid-ajim10>3.0.co;2-c}}</ref>
====Dangerous sectors==== In the U.S. the Bureau of Labor Statistics makes available extensive statistics on workplace accidents and injuries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bls.gov/iif|title=Injuries, Illnesses, and Fatalities|website=www.bls.gov|access-date=2016-04-07}}</ref> For example:
[[File:BLS US fatalities by industry 2010.png]] [[File:BLS US fatal injuries by occupation 2010.png]]
====Common injuries==== As in the United Kingdom, slips, trips and falls are common and account for 20-40% of disabling occupational injuries.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Courtney|first=T. K.|last2=Sorock|first2=G. S.|last3=Manning|first3=D. P.|last4=Collins|first4=J. W.|last5=Holbein-Jenny|first5=M. A.|date=2001-10-20|title=Occupational slip, trip, and fall-related injuries--can the contribution of slipperiness be isolated?|journal=Ergonomics|volume=44|issue=13|pages=1118–1137|doi=10.1080/00140130110085538|issn=0014-0139|pmid=11794761}}</ref> Often these accidents result in a back injury that can persist to a permanent disability. In the United States, a high risk of [[Back injury|back injuries]] occurs in the [[Healthcare industry|health care industry]]. 25% of reported injuries in health care workers in the state of Pennsylvania are for back pain.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Haladay|first=Douglas E.|last2=Blorstad|first2=Amanda L.|last3=McBrier|first3=Nicole M.|last4=Denegar|first4=Craig R.|last5=Lengerich|first5=Eugene J.|date=2012-01-01|title=Back pain among health care workers in Pennsylvania 2002-2006|journal=Work (Reading, Mass.)|volume=41|issue=1|pages=93–98|doi=10.3233/WOR-2012-1288|issn=1875-9270|pmid=22246309}}</ref> Among [[Nursing|nurses]], the prevalence of lower back pain may be as high as 72% mostly as a result of transferring patients.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schlossmacher|first=Roberta|last2=Amaral|first2=Fernando Gonçalves|date=2012-01-01|title=Low back injuries related to nursing professionals working conditions: a systematic review|journal=Work (Reading, Mass.)|volume=41 Suppl 1|pages=5737–5738|doi=10.3233/WOR-2012-0935-5737|issn=1875-9270|pmid=22317669}}</ref> Some of these injuries can be prevented with the availability of [[patient lift]]s, improved worker training, and allocation of more time to perform work procedures.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=D'Arcy|first=Laura P.|last2=Sasai|first2=Yasuko|last3=Stearns|first3=Sally C.|date=2012-04-01|title=Do assistive devices, training, and workload affect injury incidence? Prevention efforts by nursing homes and back injuries among nursing assistants|journal=Journal of Advanced Nursing|volume=68|issue=4|pages=836–845|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2648.2011.05785.x|issn=1365-2648|pmc=3203326|pmid=21787370}}</ref> Another common type of injury is [[carpal tunnel syndrome]] associated with overuse of the hands and wrists. Studies on a cohort of newly hired workers have thus far identified forceful gripping, repetitive lifting of > 1 kg, and using vibrating power tools as high risk work activities.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Evanoff|first=Bradley|last2=Dale|first2=Ann Marie|last3=Deych|first3=Elena|last4=Ryan|first4=Daniel|last5=Franzblau|first5=Alfred|date=2012-01-01|title=Risk factors for incident carpal tunnel syndrome: results of a prospective cohort study of newly-hired workers|journal=Work (Reading, Mass.)|volume=41 Suppl 1|pages=4450–4452|doi=10.3233/WOR-2012-0745-4450|issn=1875-9270|pmc=3752891|pmid=22317405}}</ref>
Additionally, noise exposure in the workplace can cause [[hearing loss]], which accounted for 14% of reported occupational illnesses in 2007.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/noise/stats.html|title=Noise and Hearing Loss Prevention|website=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|access-date=2016-07-06}}</ref> Many initiatives have been created to prevent this common workplace injury. For example, the [[Buy Quiet]] program encourages employers to purchase tools and machines that produce less noise and the [[Safe-In-Sound Award]] was created to recognize companies and program that excel in the area of hearing loss prevention.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/buyquiet/|title=Buy Quiet|website=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|access-date=2016-07-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.safeinsound.us/|title=Safe•in•Sound Excellence in Hearing Loss Prevention Award|website=www.safeinsound.us|access-date=2016-07-06}}</ref>
Accidental injection or needlestick injuries are a common injury that plague agriculture workers and veterinarians. The majority of these injuries are located to the hands or legs, and can result in mild to severe reactions, including possible hospitalization.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Buswell|first=ML.|last2=Hourigan|first2=M.|date=2015|title=Needlestick Injuries in Agriculture Workers and Prevention Programs|url=http://umash.umn.edu/publications/product/needlestick-injuries-ag-workers-prevention-programs/?|journal=Journal of Agromedicine|volume=21|issue=1|doi=10.1080/1059924X.2015.1106996|pmid=26478987|access-date=1 August 2016|via=}}</ref> Due to the wide variety of biologics used in animal agriculture, needlestick injuries can result in bacterial or fungal infections, lacerations, local inflammation, vaccine/antibiotic reactions, amputations, miscarriage, and death.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Buswell|first=M.|last2=Hourigan|first2=M.|date=9 June 2014|title=Needlestick Injuries in Livestock Workers and Prevention Programs|url=http://umash.umn.edu/publications/product/needlestick-injuries-livestock-workers-prevention-programs/?|journal=Journal of Agromedicine|volume=19|issue=2|doi=|pmid=|access-date=1 August 2016|via=}}</ref> Due to daily human-animal interactions, livestock related injuries are also a prevalent injury of agriculture workers, and are responsible for the majoriy of nonfatal worker injuries on dairy farms. Additionally, approximately 30 people die of cattle and horse-related deaths in the United States annually.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Sorge|first=U.S.|last2=Cherry|first2=C.|date=July 2014|title=Perception of the importance of human-animal interactions on cattle flow and worker safety on Minnesota dairy farms.|journal=Journal of Dairy Science|volume=97|issue=7|doi=10.3168/jds.2014-7971|pmid=24835968|via=}}</ref>
====Employees at risk==== Perhaps the most important personal factor that predisposes to an increased risk is age. In the United States in 1998 17 million workers were over age 55 and by 2018 this population is expected to more than double.<ref name="Dong 303–315" /> Workers in this age group are more likely to suffer from lower back pain that may be worsened by work conditions that normally do not affect a younger worker. Older workers are also more likely by be killed in a construction related fall.<ref name="Dong 303–315" /> They are also at higher risk for injury due to [[Presbycusis|age-related hearing loss]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Farrow|first=A.|last2=Reynolds|first2=F.|date=2012-01-01|title=Health and safety of the older worker|journal=[[Occupational Medicine (Oxford University Press journal)|Occupational Medicine]]|volume=62|issue=1|pages=4–11|doi=10.1093/occmed/kqr148|issn=1471-8405|pmid=22201131}}</ref> [[visual impairment]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Palmer|first=Keith T.|last2=D'Angelo|first2=Stefania|last3=Harris|first3=E. Clare|last4=Linaker|first4=Cathy|last5=Coggon|first5=David|date=2015-03-01|title=Sensory impairments, problems of balance and accidental injury at work: a case-control study|journal=Occupational and Environmental Medicine|volume=72|issue=3|pages=195–199|doi=10.1136/oemed-2014-102422|issn=1470-7926|pmc=4467023|pmid=25523936}}</ref> and use of multiple prescription medications<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kantor|first=Elizabeth D.|last2=Rehm|first2=Colin D.|last3=Haas|first3=Jennifer S.|last4=Chan|first4=Andrew T.|last5=Giovannucci|first5=Edward L.|date=2015-11-03|title=Trends in Prescription Drug Use Among Adults in the United States From 1999-2012|journal=JAMA|volume=314|issue=17|pages=1818–1831|doi=10.1001/jama.2015.13766|issn=1538-3598|pmc=4752169|pmid=26529160}}</ref> that has been linked to higher rates of work injuries.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Palmer|first=Keith T.|last2=D'Angelo|first2=Stefania|last3=Harris|first3=E. Clare|last4=Linaker|first4=Cathy|last5=Coggon|first5=David|date=2014-05-01|title=The role of mental health problems and common psychotropic drug treatments in accidental injury at work: a case-control study|journal=Occupational and Environmental Medicine|volume=71|issue=5|pages=308–312|doi=10.1136/oemed-2013-101948|issn=1470-7926|pmc=3984107|pmid=24627304}}</ref> In addition to age, other personal risk factors for injury include obesity <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tao|first=Xuguang Grant|last2=Lavin|first2=Robert A.|last3=Yuspeh|first3=Larry|last4=Bernacki|first4=Edward J.|date=2015-07-01|title=Is Obesity Associated With Adverse Workers' Compensation Claims Outcomes? A Pilot Study|journal=Journal of Occupational and Environmental Medicine|volume=57|issue=7|pages=795–800|doi=10.1097/JOM.0000000000000465|issn=1536-5948|pmid=26147547}}</ref> particularly its associated risk with back injury, and [[Depression (differential diagnoses)|depression]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jadhav|first=Rohan|last2=Achutan|first2=Chandran|last3=Haynatzki|first3=Gleb|last4=Rajaram|first4=Shireen|last5=Rautiainen|first5=Risto|date=2015-01-01|title=Risk Factors for Agricultural Injury: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis|journal=Journal of Agromedicine|volume=20|issue=4|pages=434–449|doi=10.1080/1059924X.2015.1075450|issn=1545-0813|pmid=26471953}}</ref>
Lack of proper education or training can also predispose an individual to an occupational injury. For example, there is limited needlestick injury awareness among agriculture workers, and there is a need for comprehensive programs to prevent needlestick injuries on livestock operations.<ref name=":1" /> Proper animal handling techniques and training, or stockmanship, can also decrease the risk of livestock injury. A handler's timing, positioning, speed, direction of movement, and sounds made will affect the behavior of an animal and consequently the safety of the handler.<ref name=":2" /> The agriculture industry has begun to focus more on proper education and training, and has made a variety of resources available to producers. For example, organizations like the Upper Midwest Agriculture Safety and Health Center [http://www.umash.umn.edu (UMASH)] have a variety of informational fact sheets and training videos easily accessible online. Additionally, organizations like Beef Quality Assurance offers stockmanship training seminars and demonstrations.
====Regulation==== In the United States, the [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration]] (OSHA) sets and enforces national standards for occupational safety across all sectors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.osha.gov/about.html|title=About OSHA|website=United States Department of Labor|access-date=2016-07-06}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== In the United Kingdom in 2013/2014, 133 people were killed at work. Of those 133 people, 89 were employed, while 44 were self-employed. In 2013/2014, an estimated 629,000 injuries occurred at work. Of these injuries 629,000 injuries, 203,000 led to more than 3 days absence from work. Of these, over 148,000 resulted in the victim being absent from work for more than 7 days.<ref name="kentcompensation">{{Cite web|url=http://www.kentcompensation.com/types-of-accident/accidents-at-work|title=Accident at Work Claims in Kent {{!}} Kent Compensation|website=www.kentcompensation.com|access-date=2016-04-07}}</ref>
====Dangerous sectors==== * Construction: 42 deaths<ref name="kentcompensation"/> * Agriculture: 27 deaths<ref name="kentcompensation"/> * Waste and Recycling: four deaths<ref name="kentcompensation"/> * Other: 60 deaths
Of all the workplace accidents that resulted in death, the most common were falls from height, contact with moving machinery and being struck by a vehicle. These types of accidents resulted in over half of all recorded deaths.<ref name="kentcompensation"/>
====Common injuries==== Slips, trips and falls account for over a third of all injuries that happen at work. Incorrect handling of items was the most common cause of injuries that led to absences from work of more than 7 days.<ref name="kentcompensation"/> Upper limb injuries represented 47.3% of workplace injuries in 2010-2011, the most common area injured.<ref name=":0" />
In all, over 1,900,000 working days were lost in 2013/2014 due to slips, trips and falls.<ref name="kentcompensation"/>
====Employees at risk==== Unsurprisingly, occupation is the biggest influence on the risk of workplace injuries. Workers new to the job are at a much higher risk of injury than more experienced staff, while shift workers and part-time staff also have a greater risk of being injured at work.<ref name="kentcompensation"/>
====Employer prosecutions==== The Health & Safety Executive (HSE) prosecuted 582 cases in 2013/2014, with at least one conviction secured in 547 cases (94%).<ref name="kentcompensation"/>
Local authorities prosecuted a total of 92 cases during the same period, with at least one conviction achieved in 89 cases (97%).<ref name="kentcompensation"/>
A total of 13,790 notices were issued by the HSE and local authorities, with over £16,700,000 issued in fines.<ref name="kentcompensation"/>
===Taiwan=== In [[Taiwan]], there were 14,261 occupational injuries recorded in 2010. 45% of these involved trauma to the upper limbs.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Vocational rehabilitation for enhancing return-to-work in workers with traumatic upper limb injuries|journal = The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date = 2013|issn = 1469-493X|pmid = 24122624|pages = CD010002|volume = 10|doi = 10.1002/14651858.CD010002.pub2|first = Wen-Hsuan|last = Hou|first2 = Ching-Chi|last2 = Chi|first3 = Heng-Lien Daniel|last3 = Lo|first4 = Ken N.|last4 = Kuo|first5 = Hung-Yi|last5 = Chuang}}</ref>{{Update inline|reason=Updated version https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29210462|date = July 2018}}
==Prevention== There are many methods of preventing or reducing industrial injuries, including anticipation of problems by [[risk assessment]], safety training, [[control banding]], [[personal protective equipment]] safety guards, mechanisms on machinery, and safety barriers. In addition, past problems can be analyzed to find their [[root cause]]s by using a technique called [[root cause analysis]]. A 2013 Cochrane review found low-quality evidence showing that inspections, especially focused inspections, can reduce work-related injuries in the long term.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mischke|first=Christina|last2=Verbeek|first2=Jos H.|last3=Job|first3=Jenny|last4=Morata|first4=Thais C.|last5=Alvesalo-Kuusi|first5=Anne|last6=Neuvonen|first6=Kaisa|last7=Clarke|first7=Simon|last8=Pedlow|first8=Robert I.|date=2013|title=Occupational safety and health enforcement tools for preventing occupational diseases and injuries|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|volume=8|pages=CD010183|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD010183.pub2|issn=1469-493X|pmid=23996220}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} This is a partial list of notable '''[[price fixing]] and [[bid rigging]] cases'''.
==US== A federal district court in February 1961 fined 29 electrical manufacturing companies and 45 individuals a total of $1,924,500 for violating the [[antitrust laws]] by fixing prices and rigging bids on heavy electrical equipment, some of which was sold to the Government.<ref>CQ almanac [http://library.cqpress.com/cqalmanac/document.php?id=cqal61-879-29203-1371699 Electrical Price Fixing Stirs Inquiry]</ref>
===Air travel=== On 1 August 2007 it was reported that [[British Airways]] has been fined £121.5 million<ref>{{cite news | title = BA gets £121.5m price-fixing fine| publisher = BBC News | date = 8 January 2007 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/6925397.stm}}</ref> for price-fixing. The fine was imposed by the [[Office of Fair Trading]] (OFT) after BA admitted to the price-fixing of fuel surcharges on long haul flights. The allegation first came to light in 2006 when [[Virgin Atlantic Airways|Virgin Atlantic]] reported the events to the authorities after it found staff members from BA and [[Virgin Atlantic]] were colluding. Virgin Atlantic have since been granted immunity by both the OFT and the [[United States Department of Justice]] who have been investigating the allegations since June 2006. The US DOJ later announced that it would fine British Airways [[$]]300 million (£148 million) for price fixing.
The allegations are thought to be linked to the resignation of commercial director Martin George and communications chief Iain Burns. Although BA said fuel surcharges were "a legitimate way of recovering costs", in May 2007 it put aside £350 million for legal fees and fines.
===Other=== * Computer Components: [[DRAM price fixing]] * Agriculture: [[Lysine price-fixing conspiracy]] * Wine, beer and liquor distribution [[Wine and Spirits Fair Dealing Act]] * Metals: [[Aluminium price-fixing conspiracy]] * Music: [[CD price fixing]]
==Denmark== * [[Christmas tree production in Denmark#2007 price fixing scandal|2007 Christmas tree price fixing scandal]]
==EU convictions==
===Beer=== On 18 April 2007 The [[European commission]] imposed fines on [[Heineken]] €219.3m, [[Grolsch]] €31.65m and [[Bavaria Brewery (Netherlands)|Bavaria]] €22.85m for operating a [[cartel|price fixing cartel]] in the [[Netherlands]], totalling €273.7m. [[InBev]], (formerly [[Interbrew]]), escaped without a penalty because it provided "decisive information" about the cartel which operated between 1996 and 1999 and others in the EU market. The brewers controlled 95% of the Dutch market, with [[Heineken]] claiming a half and the three others 15% each.<ref name = 'beer'>{{cite news | first= David| last= Gow| coauthors= | title=Heineken and Grolsch fined for price-fixing | date= 18 April 2007| publisher= | url =http://business.guardian.co.uk/story/0,,2059542,00.html | work =[[The Guardian]] | pages = | accessdate = 1 August 2007 | language = | location=London}}</ref>
[[Neelie Kroes]] said she was "very disappointed" that the collusion took place at the very highest (boardroom) level. She added, [[Heineken]], [[Grolsch]], [[Bavaria]] and [[InBev]] tried to cover their tracks by using code names and abbreviations for secret meetings to carve up the market for beer sold to [[supermarkets]], [[hotels]], [[restaurants]] and [[cafes]]. The [[price fixing]] extended to cheaper [[Store brand|own-brand]] labels and [[Rebate (marketing)|rebates]] for [[Bar (establishment)|bars]].<ref name = 'beer'/>
{{quote|This is simply unacceptable: that major beer suppliers colluded to up prices and to carve up markets among themselves.<ref name = 'beer' />|[[EU Competition Commissioner]] [[Neelie Kroes]]}}
In December 2001 Interbrew, [[Danone]] (former owner of Kronenbourg), and two other smaller brewers were fined €91m for operating a cartel in [[Belgium]] while four Luxembourg companies were fined €448,000 the same month.<ref name = 'beer' />
In 2004, [[Heineken]] and [[Kronenbourg]], the two dominant brewers in France, were fined €2.5m - with the penalty reduced for co-operating. A similar inquiry into an alleged Italian cartel was closed without proceedings while the British and German beer markets were specifically excluded.<ref name = 'beer' />
===Switchgear===
In January 2007 [[Siemens]] was fined €396 million over its role in a [[collusion]] scandal. The [[European Commission]] handed out a massive €750 million in fines to Siemens, [[Alstom]], [[Areva]], [[Schneider Electric]] and Japanese firms [[Fuji Electric]], [[Hitachi, Ltd.|Hitachi]], [[Mitsubishi Electric]], [[Toshiba]] and [[Japan AE Systems]]. Switzerland's [[ABB Group]] was a [[whistleblower]] and escaped without any fine from the Commission.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | title=Vote call by Siemens shareholders | date= 25 January 2007| publisher= | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/6296985.stm | work =[[BBC]] | pages = | accessdate = 1 August 2007 | language = }}</ref> Regulators found that the companies [[bid rigging|rigged bids for contracts]] and [[price fixing|fixed prices]] in the market for [[Switchgear|gas-insulated switchgear]] - equipment is used to control the flow of energy in electricity grids. Siemens' fine was the biggest of the companies involved because it was a ringleader, the Commission said. About 30 business premises and private homes were searched as part of the investigation.
The cartel swapped information on offers from customers and operated a quota system for the division of work. Bids were rigged so that tenders went to whichever firm was due work under the quota system. "Code names were used for both companies and individuals. They relied on anonymous email addresses for communication and used [[encryption]] for sending messages," said the Commission.<ref name=out-law>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | title=Siemens hit with €396 million price fixing fine | date= | publisher= | url=http://www.out-law.com/page-7701 | work = | pages = | accessdate = 1 August 2007 | language = }}</ref><ref>{{cite press release |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=The General Court reduces the fines of certain members of the gas insulated switchgear cartel |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_CJE-11-5_en.pdf |format=PDF |location=Luxembourg |publisher=General Court of the European Union |agency= |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=29 August 2014}}</ref> "The commission has put an end to a [[cartel]] which has cheated [[public utility]] companies and consumers for more than 16 years," said EU Competition Commissioner [[Neelie Kroes]].<ref name=out-law/>
==France== In 2005, [[Orange France]], [[SFR]] and [[Bouygues Telecom]] were found guilty and fined €534m for engaging in anti-competitive practices.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.twobirds.com/en/news/articles/2006/french-cc-fine-mobile |title=French Competition Council imposes new record fine for mobile phone operators |publisher=Bird & Bird |date=13 April 2006}}</ref>
The [[Autorité de la concurrence]] handed out fines to [[Colgate-Palmolive]], [[Henkel]], [[Unilever]], [[Procter & Gamble]], [[Reckitt Benckiser]], [[Sara Lee Corporation|Sara Lee]], [[SC Johnson]], Bolton Solitaire], [[Groupe Vendôme SA]], [[Gillette (brand)|Gillette]], [[L'Oreal]], [[Beiersdorf]] and Vania totalling €948.9million in 2016 for price-fixing on personal hygiene products.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.connexionfrance.com/court-appeal-price-fixing-fine-upheld-consumer-companies-gillette-loreal-procter-gamble-sc-johnson-18567-view-article.html |title=Huge price-fixing fine is upheld |publisher=The Connexion |date=28 October 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170209165431/http://www.connexionfrance.com/court-appeal-price-fixing-fine-upheld-consumer-companies-gillette-loreal-procter-gamble-sc-johnson-18567-view-article.html |archivedate=9 February 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==UK==
===Dairy products=== On 7 December 2007, [[Sainsbury's]], [[Asda]], [[Safeway (UK)|Safeway]], [[Dairy Crest]], [[Robert Wiseman Dairies]] and [[The Cheese Company]] have all admitted that they had secretly swapped information with each other to make shoppers pay more for milk and cheese in a £270m [[price-fixing]] conspiracy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/news/article.html?in_article_id=427337&in_page_id=2&ito=1565|title=Supermarkets fined £116m for price-fixing|publisher=|accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref> The cartel agreed in principle with the [[Office of Fair Trading]] that they conspired against the interests of consumers. In their defense, the corporations have publicly said they had been under pressure to help farmers hit by [[foot-and-mouth]], however, the OFT said "I think it is reasonable to say we don't doubt the purpose initially was to pass money back to farmers but, in general, there is no evidence that [[farm gate price]] increased as a result of the initiative. We don't know what happened to the money."
All the major UK store chains, with the exception of [[Waitrose]] and [[Marks & Spencer]], are embroiled in the OFT inquiry into [[milk]] prices in 2002 and 2003 which has been ongoing since the beginning of 2004. It was accepted by [[Asda]], Sainsbury and Safeway that stores increased the price of milk as a result of collusion. [[Dairy Crest]] and [[Robert Wiseman Dairies|Wiseman]] allegedly acted as middle men, passing on sensitive information about prices to their supposed rivals. Britain's biggest store chain [[Tesco]], and [[Morrisons]], are accused of collusion too, but vigorously deny they took part. The allegations against Tesco involve [[cheese]] as well as [[milk]] and [[butter]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2007/dec/07/supermarkets?gusrc=rss&feed=networkfront|title=OFT hands out £116m in fines for milk price fixing|first1=Fiona|last1=Walsh|first2=business|last2=editor|date=7 December 2007|publisher=|accessdate=29 October 2016|via=The Guardian}}</ref>
If the OFT proves its case, the retailers could theoretically face fines of up to 10 per cent of their worldwide turnover, which in Tesco's case would amount to £4.3bn. The Office of Fair Trading told Sainsbury's, Asda, Safeway, Dairy Crest, Wiseman and The Cheese Company they faced maximum fines of £116m, though the final figure may be as low as £80m as a result of their co-operation. [[Sainsbury's]] told the [[London Stock Exchange]] that its fine was £26m. The fine for [[Safeway (UK)|Safeway]] is thought to be between £8m and £10m; £9m for [[Dairy Crest]] and £6m for [[Robert Wiseman Dairies|Robert Wiseman]]. It is unclear who blew the whistle on the price-fixing but [[Arla Foods|Arla]], the dairy processor, will escape a fine after fully co-operating with authorities. Consumer advocate [[Which?]] Ltd complained that, despite overpaying £270m, [[consumer]]s would not receive any refunds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.independent.co.uk/business/news/article3233342.ece|title=Milked! Supermarkets admit secret price-fixing|publisher=|accessdate=29 October 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080706145752/http://news.independent.co.uk/business/news/article3233342.ece|archivedate=6 July 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Construction=== In April 2008, The [[Office of Fair Trading]] named 112 companies that it says colluded to inflate the cost of a wide range of contracts worth billions of pounds, including tenders for schools, universities and hospitals.<ref name='building'/>
The list includes several publicly listed companies, including [[Balfour Beatty]], [[Kier Group]] and [[Carillion]], with 80 of the firms have already admitted participating in some form of bid-rigging, or have applied for leniency in return for assisting the OFT. The allegations centre around "cover pricing", in which firms secretly agreed the prices they would submit during a tender process. A firm that did not want to win the contract would submit a price that was much too high. In some cases, the eventual successful bidder would then reward them with a secret payment. This bid rigging often involved false invoices. The OFT declined to comment on the value of the fraud.<ref name='building'>[http://www.oft.gov.uk/news/press/2008/52-08 OFT issues statement of objections against 112 construction companies] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080420231329/http://www.oft.gov.uk/news/press/2008/52-08 |date=20 April 2008 }}</ref>
===Financial=== In April 2003, The London office of [[ABN Amro]] was fined £900,000 for helping a US client, Oechsle International Advisers, to rig share prices. The fine was the [[Financial Services Authority|FSA]]'s fifth biggest, and is the largest involving market abuse on the [[London Stock Exchange]].<ref name='abm'/>
ABN's then joint head of the UK equity trading desk, Michael Ackers, has been fined £70,000 for "market misconduct." The FSA decided that traders in ABN Amro Equities (UK), known as AAE, "accepted improper instructions whose apparent purpose was to push the closing market price of certain shares to a higher level than would otherwise have been the case". This happened on three separate occasions between April and October 1998 in respect of shares in Carlton Communications, British Biotech, Volkswagen and Metro. Angelo Iannone, the head of ABN's international sales trading desk in New York, had had a long-standing relationship with Oechsle and one of its fund managers, Andrew Parlin. They agreed to increase the price of the shares in question at the end of certain days' trading, to make the prices look better in clients' portfolios.<ref name='abm'>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/abn-fined-pound900000-for-price-rigging-595508.html|title=US|publisher=|accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref>
{{quote|Trading in stocks simply to move the market price is a serious abuse: it distorts market forces and undermines investors' confidence in the integrity of the prices quoted on exchanges...These were not isolated events. The repeated nature of the breaches demonstrates the absence of a robust compliance environment on the firm's trading floor. We view with particular seriousness misconduct that occurs in the context of a firm's inadequate investment in compliance procedures, policies and training. Investors need to be confident that they are dealing in clean and orderly markets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsa.gov.uk/pages/Library/Communication/PR/2003/053.shtml|title=FSA fines ABN Amro Equities 900,000 for market misconduct|first=The Financial Services Authority, 25 The North Colonnade, Canary Wharf, London E14|last=5HS|publisher=|accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref>|Carol Sergeant, Managing Director of the [[Financial Services Authority|FSA]]}}
==Australia==
===Airlines===
The [[Australian Competition & Consumer Commission]] (ACCC) has taken several airlines to the [[Federal Court of Australia]] seeking penalties for alleged price fixing contraventions. As of 2011, the ACCC's activities are:
====Qantas==== The ACCC instituted proceedings against [[Qantas]] seeking penalties for alleged price fixing contraventions relating to fuel [[fee|surcharges]] applied to international carriage of [[Cargo#Air|air cargo]] between 2002 and early 2006.<ref name="accc.gov.au">[http://www.accc.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/847215/fromItemId/621556 ACCC launches its first cases in alleged air freight cartel, Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, 28 October 2008]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref> The conduct concerned collusion between competitors over fuel surcharges which the ACCC alleged and Qantas admitted had the purpose and likely effect of fixing or maintaining a component of the price for air cargo services. The Federal Court in [[Sydney]] ordered Qantas to pay $20 million in [[pecuniary]] penalties for breaching the price fixing provisions of the [[Trade Practices Act 1974]].<ref>[http://www.accc.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/853210/fromItemId/621556 Court orders Qantas to pay $20 million for price fixing, Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, 11 December 2008]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/business/qantas-cops-fine-for-price-fixing-20081211-6we9.html Qantas cops fine for price fixing, 11 December 2008]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref><ref>{{cite AustLII|FCA|1976|2008|litigants=Australian Competition and Consumer Commission v Qantas Airways Limited |courtname=auto}}.</ref>
====British Airways==== The ACCC instituted proceedings against [[British Airways]] seeking penalties for alleged price fixing contraventions relating to fuel surcharges applied to international carriage of air cargo between 2002 and early 2006.<ref name="accc.gov.au"/> The Federal Court in Sydney ordered British Airways to pay $5 million in pecuniary penalties for breaching the price fixing provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974. The ACCC instituted proceedings alleging British Airways reached an understanding with [[Lufthansa Cargo]] in relation to the imposition of fuel surcharges on some of its international air cargo services between 2002 and early 2006.<ref>[http://www.accc.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/853209/fromItemId/621556 Court orders British Airways PLC to pay $5 million for price fixing, Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, 11 December 2008]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref><ref>{{cite AustLII|FCA|1977|2008|litigants=Australian Competition and Consumer Commission v British Airways PLC |courtname=auto}}.</ref>
====Singapore Airlines Cargo==== The ACCC alleged that [[Singapore Airlines Cargo]], between 2001 and 2005, entered into arrangements or understandings with other international air cargo carriers that had the purpose or effect of fixing the price of a fuel surcharge and a security surcharge that was applied to air cargo carried by Singapore Airlines Cargo and other [[airlines]] including to and from Australia.<ref>[http://www.accc.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/854765/fromItemId/621556 ACCC institutes proceedings against Singapore Airlines Cargo Pte Ltd for alleged price-fixing, Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, 22 December 2008]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/12/22/2453260.htm Singapore Airlines to defend ACCC price fixing claim, ABC News, 22 December 2008]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref>
====Air France==== The ACCC instituted proceedings against [[Air France]] seeking penalties for alleged price fixing between early 2003 and 2006. The alleged contraventions relate to fuel surcharges applied to international carriage of air cargo during that period.<ref>[http://www.accc.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/860197/fromItemId/621556 ACCC institutes proceedings against more airlines in alleged air freight cartel, Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, 10 February 2009]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref> The Federal Court in Sydney ordered pecuniary penalties ($6 million in total with KLM) for breaching the price fixing provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974. The ACCC alleged the airline reached understandings with other international airlines in relation to the imposition of fuel surcharges applied to international carriage of air cargo during that period between early 2003 and 2006. Air France admitted to making and giving effect to illegal price fixing understandings with Lufthansa, repeatedly exchanging assurances with Lufthansa in the implementation of fuel surcharge increases for international carriage of air cargo across their global networks.<ref name="Australian Competition 2011">[http://www.accc.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/861037/fromItemId/621556 Court orders airlines to pay a total of $16 million in penalties for price fixing, Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, 16 February 2009]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref><ref name="theaustralian.com.au">[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/four-airlines-fined-16m-for-price-fixing/story-fn3dxix6-1111118868606 Federal Court fines Air France, KLM, Martinari and Cargolux $16 million for price-fixing cartel, The Australian, 16 February 2009]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref>
====Koninklijke Luchtvaart Maatschappij (KLM)==== The ACCC instituted proceedings against [[Koninklijke Luchtvaart Maatschappij|KLM]] seeking penalties for alleged price fixing between early 2003 and 2006. The alleged contraventions relate to fuel surcharges applied to international carriage of air cargo during that period.<ref name="ReferenceA">[http://www.accc.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/860197/fromItemId/621556 ACCC institutes proceedings against more airlines in alleged air freight cartel, 10 February 2009]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref> The Federal Court in Sydney ordered pecuniary penalties ($6 million in total with Air France) for breaching the price fixing provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974. The ACCC alleged the airline reached understandings with other international airlines in relation to the imposition of fuel surcharges applied to international carriage of air cargo during that period between early 2003 and 2006. KLM admitted to making and giving effect to illegal price fixing understandings with Lufthansa, repeatedly exchanging assurances with Lufthansa in the implementation of fuel surcharge increases for international carriage of air cargo across their global networks.<ref name="Australian Competition 2011"/><ref name="theaustralian.com.au"/>
====Martinair Holland==== The ACCC instituted proceedings against [[Martinair Holland|Martinair]] seeking penalties for alleged price fixing between early 2003 and 2006. The alleged contraventions relate to fuel surcharges applied to international carriage of air cargo during that period.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The Federal Court in Sydney ordered pecuniary penalties of $5 million for breaching the price fixing provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974. The ACCC alleged the airline reached understandings with other international airlines in relation to the imposition of fuel surcharges applied to international carriage of air cargo during that period between early 2003 and 2006. Martinair admitted that by no later than early 2003, it had arrived and gave effect to illegal price fixing understandings with KLM and [[Cargolux]] that they would have discussions and exchange and confirm information with each other in relation to the application of fuel surcharges on cargo carried internationally by air across their respective global networks.<ref name="Australian Competition 2011"/><ref name="theaustralian.com.au"/>
====Cargolux==== The ACCC instituted proceedings against [[Cargolux]] seeking penalties for alleged price fixing between early 2003 and 2006. The alleged contraventions relate to fuel surcharges applied to international carriage of air cargo during that period.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The Federal Court in Sydney ordered pecuniary penalties of $5 million for breaching the price fixing provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974. The ACCC alleged the airline reached understandings with other international airlines in relation to the imposition of fuel surcharges applied to international carriage of air cargo during that period between early 2003 and 2006. Cargolux admitted to making and giving effect to illegal price fixing understandings with each of Lufthansa, Air France and KLM that each of them would impose a fuel surcharge on cargo carried internationally by air across their networks, (except where local conditions in a particular port or in a particular geographic area prevented the imposition, or full imposition, of the fuel surcharge).<ref name="Australian Competition 2011"/><ref name="theaustralian.com.au"/>
====Cathay Pacific==== The ACCC instituted proceedings in the Federal Court against [[Cathay Pacific]]. The ACCC alleged that between 2000 and 2006, Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd entered into over 70 arrangements or understandings with other international air cargo carriers that had the purpose or effect of fixing the price of a fuel surcharge, a security surcharge and rates that were applied to air cargo carried by Cathay Pacific and other airlines. The ACCC alleged that the arrangements or understandings were reached in countries including [[Singapore]], [[Indonesia]], [[Hong Kong]], [[United Arab Emirates]], [[India]], [[Japan]] and [[Italy]]. The ACCC sort declarations, injunctive relief, pecuniary penalties, and costs.<ref>[http://www.accc.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/870718/fromItemId/621556 ACCC institutes proceedings against Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd for alleged price-fixing of air freight, Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, 30 April 2009]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.impactpub.com.au/aircargo/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3605&Itemid=60&date=2010-04-01 ACCC takes legal action against Cathay Pacific, Aircargo Asia Pacific, 30 April 2009]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref>
====Emirates==== The ACCC instituted proceedings in the Federal Court against [[Emirates (airline)|Emirates]]. The ACCC alleged that between 2002 and 2006, Emirates entered into arrangements or understandings with other international air cargo carriers that had the purpose and effect of fixing the price of certain fuel surcharges, security surcharges and rates that were applied to air cargo carried by Emirates and other airlines. The ACCC alleged that the arrangements or understandings were reached in countries including Singapore, Indonesia, Hong Kong, United Arab Emirates and India. The ACCC sort declarations, [[injunctive relief]], pecuniary penalties, and costs.<ref>[http://www.accc.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/888604/fromItemId/621556 ACCC takes action against Emirates for alleged air freight price fixing, Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, 18 August 2009]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref><ref>[http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-national/emirates-accused-of-freight-pricefixing-20090818-eovz.html Emirates accused of freight price-fixing, Sydney Morning Herald, 18 August 2009]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref>
====Garuda Indonesia==== The ACCC instituted proceedings in the Federal Court against [[Garuda Indonesia]]. The ACCC alleged that between 2001 and 2006, Garuda Indonesia entered into arrangements or understandings with other international air cargo carriers that had the purpose or effect of fixing the price of a fuel surcharge and a security surcharge that were applied to air cargo carried by PT Garuda Indonesia Ltd and other airlines. The ACCC alleged that the arrangements or understandings were reached in Indonesia and Hong Kong. The ACCC sort declarations, injunctive relief, pecuniary penalties, and costs.<ref>[http://www.accc.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/891294/fromItemId/621556 ACCC institutes proceedings against PT Garuda Indonesia Ltd for alleged price fixing of air freight, Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, 2 September 2009]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aviationbusiness.com.au/news/accc-targets-garuda|title=ACCC targets Garuda - Aviation Business|publisher=|accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref>
====Thai Airways==== The ACCC alleged that between 2001 and 2006, [[Thai Airways]] entered into arrangements or understandings with other international air cargo carriers in specific countries that had the purpose or effect of fixing the price of fuel surcharges and security surcharges that were applied to air cargo carried by Thai Airways and other airlines. The ACCC alleged that the arrangements or understandings were reached in Singapore, Indonesia and Hong Kong – plus Thailand in the case of a security surcharge called a crisis surcharge – for surcharges applied to cargo originating in those countries. The ACCC sort declarations, injunctive relief, pecuniary penalties, and costs.<ref>[http://www.accc.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/899383/fromItemId/621556 ACCC institutes proceedings against Thai Airways for alleged price fixing of air freight, Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, 28 October 2009]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.eyefortransport.com/content/thai-airways-falls-foul-accc Thai Airways falls foul of ACCC, Eye For Transport, 29 October 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110228083716/http://www.eyefortransport.com/content/thai-airways-falls-foul-accc |date=28 February 2011 }}. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref>
====Korean Air==== The ACCC instituted proceedings in the Federal Court against [[Korean Air]]. The ACCC alleged that between 2001 and 2006, Korean Air entered into arrangements or understandings with other international air cargo carriers that had the purpose or effect of fixing the price of a fuel surcharge, a security surcharge and a customs fee that were applied to air cargo carried by Korean Air and other airlines. The ACCC alleged that the arrangements or understandings were reached in Korea, Indonesia and Hong Kong for surcharges applied to cargo originating in those countries and in Indonesia for a customs fee applied to cargo originating in that country. The ACCC sort declarations, injunctive relief, pecuniary penalties, and costs.<ref>[http://www.accc.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/917336 ACCC institutes proceedings against Korean Air Lines Co. Ltd, Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, 5 March 2010]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref><ref>[http://aircargo.net.au/?p=95 Australia targets Korean, Air cargo Net, 12 March 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120707102929/http://aircargo.net.au/?p=95 |date=7 July 2012 }}. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref>
====Malaysian Airlines==== The ACCC instituted proceedings in the Federal Court against [[Malaysian Airlines]] and its wholly owned cargo subsidiary [[MASkargo]]. The ACCC alleged that between 2001 and 2006, Malaysian Airlines and Malaysia Airlines Cargo entered into arrangements or understandings with other international air cargo carriers that had the purpose or effect of fixing the price of a fuel surcharge and a security surcharge that were applied to air cargo carried by them and other airlines. The ACCC alleged that arrangements or understandings were reached in Indonesia and Hong Kong for fuel surcharges applied to cargo originating in those countries. The ACCC also alleged arrangements or understandings were reached in Indonesia, Hong Kong and Singapore for a security surcharge applied to cargo originating in those countries. The ACCC sort declarations, injunctive relief, pecuniary penalties, and costs.<ref>[http://www.accc.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/923374/fromItemId/621556 ACCC institutes proceedings against Malaysian airline companies for alleged price fixing of air freight, Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, 13 April 2010]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref><ref>[http://aircargo.net.au/?p=174 MAS latest target for price-fixing charges, Air Cargo, 20 April 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811063146/http://aircargo.net.au/?p=174 |date=11 August 2011 }} ]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.aircargoworld.com/Archive/2010/The-Week/April-2010/Malaysia-Airlines-in-court-on-cartel-allegations Malaysia Airlines in court on "cartel" allegations, Air Cargo World, 13 April 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726151918/http://www.aircargoworld.com/Archive/2010/The-Week/April-2010/Malaysia-Airlines-in-court-on-cartel-allegations |date=26 July 2011 }}. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref>
====Japan Airlines==== The ACCC instituted proceedings in the Federal Court today against [[Japan Airlines]]. The ACCC alleged that between 2002 and 2006, Japan Airlines, Ltd. entered into arrangements or understandings with other international air cargo carriers that had the purpose or effect of fixing the price of a fuel surcharge and a security surcharge that were applied to air cargo carried by them and other airlines. The ACCC alleged that arrangements or understandings were reached in Singapore, Hong Kong and Japan for fuel surcharges applied to cargo originating in those countries. The ACCC also alleged arrangements or understandings were reached in Singapore and Hong Kong for a security surcharge applied to cargo originating in those countries. The ACCC sort declarations, injunctive relief, pecuniary penalties, and costs.<ref>[http://www.accc.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/928666/fromItemId/621556 ACCC institutes proceedings against Japan Airlines International Co., Ltd. for alleged price fixing of air freight, Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, 17 May 2010]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref><ref name="heraldsun.com.au">[http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/breaking-news/price-fixing-charge-for-air-nz-and-jal-accc-says/story-e6frf7ko-1225867852007 Price fixing charge for Air NZ and JAL, ACCC says, Herald Sun, 17 May 2010]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref> The Federal Court in Melbourne ordered a $5.5 million penalty against Japan Airlines International Co Ltd (JAL) for breaching the price fixing provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974*. JAL admitted to making and giving effect to illegal price fixing understandings with other international airlines that each of them would impose a fuel surcharge and an insurance and security surcharge on cargo carried internationally by air across their networks.<ref>[http://www.accc.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/982436/fromItemId/621556 Japan Airlines penalised $5.5 million for price fixing, Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, 11 April 2010]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref>
====Air New Zealand==== The ACCC instituted proceedings in the Federal Court against [[Air New Zealand]]. The ACCC alleged that between 2002 and 2006, Air New Zealand entered into arrangements or understandings with other international air cargo carriers that had the purpose or effect of fixing the price of a fuel surcharge and a security surcharge that were applied to air cargo carried by them and other airlines. The ACCC alleged that arrangements or understandings were reached in Singapore Hong Kong and Japan for fuel surcharges applied to cargo originating in those countries. The ACCC also alleged arrangements or understandings were reached in Singapore and Hong Kong for a security surcharge applied to cargo originating in those countries. The ACCC sort declarations, injunctive relief, pecuniary penalties, and costs.<ref name="heraldsun.com.au"/><ref>[http://www.accc.gov.au/content/index.phtml/itemId/928664/fromItemId/621556 ACCC institutes proceedings against Air New Zealand Ltd for alleged price fixing of air freight, Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, 17 May 2010]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.dynamicbusiness.com.au/legal/air-new-zealand-accc-1539.html Air New Zealand caught fixing prices by ACCC, Business Dynamics, 17 May 2010]. Retrieved 18 May 2011</ref>
===Cosmetics skincare=== In 2007, skincare cosmetics company Jurlique was fined AUD$3.4 million where the company entered into agreements with resellers where one of the terms included that the products were not to be sold for prices less than a price specified by Jurlique.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/highest-ever-penalty-for-resale-price-maintenance-against-skincare-cosmetics-company|title=Highest ever penalty for resale price maintenance against skincare, cosmetics company Jurlique: $3.4 million|first=Australian Competition and Consumer|last=Commission|date=23 February 2013|publisher=|accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox event | title = Radiohead stage collapse | image = Downsview Park (Toronto, Ontario) (9703307650) (2).jpg | caption = Downsview Park | date = 16 June 2012 | place = [[Downsview Park]]
[[Toronto]], Canada | cause = | reported injuries = 3 | reported death(s) = 1 | reported missing = | reported property damage = | inquiries = | inquest = | suspects = | charges = | verdict = | convictions = }}On 16 June 2012, during the setup at Toronto's [[Downsview Park]] for the final concert of [[Radiohead|Radiohead's]] North American tour, the roof of the temporary stage collapsed, killing drum technician Scott Johnson and injuring three others. Radiohead and artists including [[Keane (band)|Keane]], [[White Lies (band)|White Lies]], [[Dan Snaith|Caribou]], and [[Elton John]] offered tributes and condolences. In June 2013, [[Live Nation]] Canada Inc, two other organisations and an engineer were charged with 13 charges under Ontario health and safety laws. The hearing began in June 2015, but a mistrial was declared after the judge was appointed to [[Ontario Superior Court of Justice|Ontario Superior Court]] and lost [[jurisdiction]]. The case was dropped in September 2017 under the [[R v Jordan (2016)|Jordan ruling]], which puts time limits on cases. Radiohead condemned the decision. The chief coroner of Ontario is due to hold an inquest into Johnson's death. == Collapse == On 16 June 2012, the English [[alternative rock]] band [[Radiohead]] were due to perform the final concert of their 2012 North American tour in support of their eighth album, ''[[The King of Limbs]]'', in [[Downsview Park]], Toronto. The tour had extensive visual components and required 11 trucks to transport its equipment. Radiohead were due to have been on stage for the [[soundcheck]], but construction of the temporary stage was behind schedule.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/music/article-radioheads-return-to-toronto-why-theyre-still-angry-about-the-fatal/|title=Radiohead’s return to Toronto: Why they’re still angry about the fatal stage collapse that nearly caused them to call it quits|last=Dekel|first=Jonathan|date=16 July 2018|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|access-date=18 July 2018|subscription=yes}} The band was sequestered nearby while their [[road crew]] prepared equipment.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/radiohead-drum-technician-death-1.4422702|title='I feel so let down by Canada': Radiohead and drum tech's parents demand answers in his Toronto death|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-11-30|language=en}} The weather was calm, with light winds forecast.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/story/2012/06/17/toronto-stage-collapse.html|title=Radiohead 'shattered' by crew member's death|date=17 June 2012|accessdate=21 June 2012|publisher=CBC News}} At 2pm, Radiohead’s business manager Ade Bullock noticed that scaffolding on the stage appeared to be drooping, and took a photograph, but thought: "What do I know about engineering?" At 4pm, an hour before the gates were due to open to concertgoers, the roof of the stage collapsed. Drummer [[Philip Selway]] recalled a sound "like an enormous cabinet of glasses falling over". Drum technician Scott Johnson was killed instantly by a falling video monitor weighing 2,270 kilograms. Three other members of Radiohead's crew were injured, one seriously.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-18474835|title=Radiohead stage collapse 'kills one' in Canada|work=BBC News|accessdate=28 September 2014}} The band's light show and much of their musical equipment was also destroyed. The concert was cancelled and Radiohead's tour dates in Europe were postponed.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/story/2012/06/21/toronto-radiohead-concerts-postponed-after-stage-collapse.html|title=Radiohead postpones more shows after stage collapse|last=|first=|date=21 June 2012|work=|accessdate=21 June 2012|publisher=[[CBC News]]}} Radiohead considered abandoning touring after the collapse. Selway said: "When we came away, it was, 'God, do we want to do this ever again?’ If it causes this, ''can'' we do it?" They decided to continue the tour as a way of "working through the trauma". At a vigil before their next performance three weeks later, Radiohead offered their crew the chance to leave without judgment; all chose to stay. == Tributes == Johnson, 33, from [[Doncaster]], South Yorkshire, had worked with acts including [[Robyn]], the [[The Killers|Killers]], [[Keane (band)|Keane]] and [[White Lies (band)|White Lies]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-18479402|title=Radiohead stage fall victim named|last=|first=|date=18 June 2012|work=[[BBC News]]|access-date=30 November 2017|language=en-GB}}{{Cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/thepitch/1310-waiting-on-justice-for-the-radiohead-stage-collapse-that-killed-scott-johnson/|title=Waiting on Justice for the Radiohead Stage Collapse That Killed Scott Johnson|last=Marc|first=Hogan|date=3 October 2016|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=1 December 2017}} Shortly after the collapse, Selway wrote on Radiohead's website: "We have all been shattered by the loss of Scott Johnson, our friend and colleague. He was a lovely man, always positive, supportive and funny; a highly skilled and valued member of our great road crew. We will miss him very much. Our thoughts and love are with Scott's family and all those close to him." Tributes came from artists including Keane,{{Cite news|url=http://www.nme.com/news/music/keane-2-8-1276675|title=Keane pay tribute to Radiohead drum technician after stage collapse - NME|date=2012-06-18|work=NME|access-date=2017-12-01|language=en-US}} White Lies, and [[Dan Snaith|Caribou]], the Canadian band set to open for Radiohead. [[Elton John]] called Johnson's family to offer his condolences. All of Radiohead and their road crew attended Johnson's funeral. In July, Radiohead paid tribute to Johnson at their first concert after the collapse, in [[Nîmes]], France, performing their single "[[Reckoner]]" as an [[encore]] while screens showed images of Johnson.{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/radiohead-honor-late-drum-tech-at-first-show-since-stage-collapse-20120711|title=Radiohead Honor Late Drum Tech at First Show Since Stage Collapse | Music News|author=Rolling Stone|date=11 July 2012|work=Rolling Stone|accessdate=16 August 2012}} Selway's second solo album, ''[[Weatherhouse (album)|Weatherhouse]]'' (2014), and Radiohead's ninth album, ''[[A Moon Shaped Pool]]'' (2016)'','' are dedicated to Johnson. Johnson's parents used royalties from Keane's charity EP ''Upstairs At United - Vol. 5'',{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/carly-wilford/keane-recording_b_1932495.html|title=Exclusive - Keane Go Analogue For Legendary United Record Pressing in Nashville|date=2012-10-04|work=HuffPost UK|access-date=2018-07-20|language=en-GB}} along with almost £3500 raised by Radiohead fans and £1200 of church and family donations, to create the Scott Johnson Bursary Fund. The fund distributes [[drum kit]]s to schools and teachers with help from [[Yamaha Corporation|Yamaha]] and the music shop where Johnson once worked. In 2015, Selway, [[Stephen Morris (musician)|Stephen Morris]] of [[New Order (band)|New Order]] and [[Guy Garvey]] of [[Elbow (band)|Elbow]] presented a drum kit in Johnson's honour to the [[Manchester Central Library]]. == Case == ''[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]'' described the collapse as part of a "sad streak of stage-related accidents", such as the 2011 [[Indiana State Fair stage collapse]], that had prompted "industry soul-searching". In June 2013, after a year-long investigation, the [[Ministry of Labour (Ontario)|Ontario Ministry of Labour]] charged [[Live Nation]] Canada Inc, Live Nation Ontario Concerts GP Inc, Optex Staging & Services Inc and the engineer who designed the stage, Domenic Cugliari, with 13 charges under Ontario health and safety laws.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/story/2013/06/07/toronto-live-nation-ontario-ministry-of-labour-optex.html|title=Live Nation, engineer charged in Radiohead stage collapse|date=7 June 2013|work=[[CBC News]]|accessdate=8 June 2013}} Prosecutor Dave McCaskill sought to prove that Cugliari "miscalculated the total gross weight of the stage roof and its attachments" by approximately 7,260 kilograms. Live Nation issued a statement denying any wrongdoing and vowing to "vigourously defend" itself. The hearing was set to begin in June 2015, but was postponed to November as Optex had no lawyer; Optex president Dale Martin eventually represented himself. All defendants pleaded not guilty. After 15 days of hearings, during which Radiohead's managers and crew gave evidence, the court ordered another 15 days throughout 2016. Shortly before June, following the defence's request for more time to present its case, the court scheduled further dates in December and January. In June 2016, the defence persuaded the judge, Shaun Nakatsuru, to drop two of the charges against Live Nation and one charge against Optex for lack of evidence. In June 2017, Nakatsuru declared a mistrial as he had been appointed to the [[Ontario Superior Court of Justice|Ontario Superior Court]] and had lost [[jurisdiction]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/music/2017/06/19/new-trial-ordered-in-deadly-stage-collapse-at-toronto-radiohead-concert.html|title=New trial ordered in deadly stage collapse at Downsview Radiohead concert {{!}} The Star|work=thestar.com|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en}} As a new trial would not have begun until May 2018, the new judge, Ann Nelson, ruled in favour of the defendants' application to have the case dropped under the [[R v Jordan (2016)|Jordan ruling]], which rules that any person charged with an offence has the right to be tried within a "reasonable" timeframe. Nakatsuru had declined a previous application from the defence. Radiohead released a statement saying: "We are appalled by the decision … This is an insult to the memory of Scott Johnson, his parents and our crew. It offers no consolation, closure or assurance that this kind of accident will not happen again."{{Cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/radiohead-on-stalled-stage-collapse-case-we-are-appalled/|title=Radiohead on Stalled Stage Collapse Case: "We Are Appalled"|last=Monroe|first=Jazz|date=8 September 2017|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=20 August 2018}} Radiohead's management and Johnsons's parents met British members of parliament, who wrote to the [[Canadian High Commissions|Canadian High Commission]] demanding the case be reopened. In November 2017, it was announced that the chief coroner of Ontario, Dirk Huyer, will hold an inquest into Johnson's death. In a statement, Radiohead said: "While this is welcomed it does not bring those responsible for Scott's death to account, and it provides no justice for Scott and his family. We urge the Canadian authorities to look more closely into the treatment of the Downsview stage collapse and indeed all workplace deaths to ensure that accidents such as this can be prevented in the future."{{Cite news|url=http://www.nme.com/news/music/radiohead-respond-to-inquest-into-stage-collapse-that-killed-a-drum-tech-2166951|title=Radiohead respond to inquest into stage collapse that killed their drum tech - NME|last=Levine|first=Nick|date=30 November 2017|work=[[NME]]|access-date=25 July 2018|language=en-UK}} As of July 2018 no date had been set for the inquest.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/jul/20/thom-yorke-addresses-stage-collapse-that-killed-radiohead-drum-technician|title=Thom Yorke addresses stage collapse that killed Radiohead's drum technician|last=Snapes|first=Laura|date=2018-07-20|website=[[The Guardian]]|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-21}} On 19 July 2018, Radiohead performed at Toronto's [[Scotiabank Arena]], their first performance in Toronto since the collapse. On stage, Yorke condemned the lack of progress in the case and Radiohead held a [[Moment of silence|minute of silence]] before performing their final song, the 1997 single "[[Karma Police]]". ''[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]'' journalist Jill Krajewski noted the new meaning in the lyrics "Karma police / arrest this man".{{Cite news|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/7xq8yd/radioheads-thom-yorke-calls-out-toronto-for-lack-of-action-after-stage-collapse|title=Radiohead’s Thom Yorke Calls Out Toronto for Lack of Action After Stage Collapse|last=Jill|first=Krajewski|date=20 July 2018|work=[[Vice (website)|Vice]]|access-date=22 July 2018|language=en-us}} == References == {{reflist}}{{Radiohead}} [[Category:2012 industrial disasters]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in Canada]] [[Category:Disasters in Canada]] [[Category:Building collapses in 2012]] [[Category:2012 disasters in Canada]] [[Category:Disasters at musical events]]

{{Infobox Wrestling event |name=Rey de Reyes (2005) |image=AAAReydeReyes2005.jpg |caption=Official logo of the Rey de Reyes broadcast |promotion=[[Lucha Libre AAA World Wide|AAA]] |date=March 11, 2005<ref name="Rey2005">{{cite web | url = http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/rey.html#2005 | title = Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion Rey de Reyes Tournament|accessdate = February 19, 2009 | date= March 11, 2005| publisher= ProWrestlingHistory.com}}</ref> |venue= Convention Center |city=[[Ciudad Madero]], [[Tamaulipas]], [[Mexico]]<ref name="Rey2005"/> |attendance= |liveevent=Y |lastevent=[[Guerra de Titanes (2004)]] |nextevent=[[Triplemanía XIII]] |event=[[Rey de Reyes]] |lastevent2=[[Rey de Reyes (2004)]] |nextevent2=[[Rey de Reyes (2006)]] }} The '''Rey de Reyes 2005''' ([[Spanish language|Spanish]] for "King of Kings") was the ninth annual [[Rey de Reyes]] [[professional wrestling]] tournament and show, produced by the Mexican [[wrestling promotion]] [[Lucha Libre AAA World Wide|AAA]]. The event took place on March 11, 2005 in the Convention Center in [[Ciudad Madero]], [[Tamaulipas]], [[Mexico]]. The main focus of the 2005 Rey de Reyes show was the ninth annual Rey de Reyes tournament, which featured an elimination match with six men competing for the Rey de Reyes title. As in the previous year, [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling|TNA]] representatives competed in the finals. The finalists did not have to qualify but were announced in the weeks leading up to the events. The finalists were: [[La Parka II|La Parka]], [[Latin Lover (wrestler)|Latin Lover]], [[Abismo Negro]], [[Chessman (wrestler)|Chessman]], [[Jeff Jarrett]], [[Konnan]] and [[Cibernético]]. The undercard included a [[Kick Boxing]] match between Humberto Galanez Gabuz and Ty Landez. In the semi-main event [[Octagoncito (AAA)|Octagoncito]] faced [[Pequeño Black Warrior|Mini Psicosis]] in a ''[[Lucha de Apuestas]]'' where both men put their masks on the line.
==Production== ===Background=== Starting in 1997 and every year since then the Mexican ''[[Lucha Libre]]'', or [[professional wrestling]], [[wrestling promotion|company]] [[Lucha Libre AAA World Wide|AAA]] has held a [[Rey de Reyes]] (Spanish for "King of Kings') show in the spring. The 1997 version was held in February,<ref name="Rey1997">{{cite web | url = http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/rey.html#1997 | title = Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion Rey de Reyes | accessdate = February 19, 2009 | date=February 21, 1997 | publisher= ProWrestlingHistory.com}}</ref> while all subsequent Rey de Reyes shows were held in March. As part of their annual Rey de Reyes event AAA holds the [[eponym]]ious Rey de Reyes tournament to determine that specific year's ''Rey''.<ref name=YIR1997>{{cite news|title=1997 Especial!|work=Box y Lucha Magazine|pages=2–28|id=issue 2332|date=January 7, 1998|language=Spanish}}</ref> Most years the show hosts both the qualifying round and the final match, but on occasion the qualifying matches have been held prior to the event as part of AAA's weekly television shows.<ref name=Lucha2004>{{cite news|title=Número Especial - Lo mejor de la lucha libre mexicana durante el 2004|work=SuperLuchas|id=Issue 91|date=January 24, 2005|language=Spanish}}</ref> The traditional format consists of four preliminary rounds, each a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic elimination matches|Four-man elimination match]] with each of the four winners face off in the tournament finals, again under elimination rules.<ref name="Rey1997"/> There have been years where AAA has employed a different format to determine a winner.<ref name=Lucha2004/> The winner of the Rey de Reyes tournament is given a large ornamental sword to symbolize their victory, but is normally not guaranteed any other rewards for winning the tournament, although some years becoming the Rey de Reyes has earned the winner a match for the [[AAA Mega Championship]]. From 1999 through 2009 AAA also held an annual ''[[AAA Reina de Reinas Championship|Reina de Reinas]]'' ("Queen of Queens") tournament, but later turned that into an actual championship that could be defended at any point during the year, abandoning the annual tournament concept.<ref name=Reinas1999>{{Cite book | author=Royal Duncan and Gary Will | title=Wrestling Title Histories | publisher=Archeus Communications |chapter= Mexico: AAA Reina de Reinas | page= 400 | year= 2000 | isbn=0-9698161-5-4}}</ref><ref name=Reinas12>{{cite news | author = SuperLuchas staff | title = Lo Mejor de la Lucha Libre Mexicana 2008 | work =SuperLuchas | id = issue 296 | date = January 6, 2008 | url=http://superluchas.net/?p=11145 | accessdate = July 11, 2009| language = Spanish}}</ref><ref name=Reinas13>{{cite web | url= http://superluchas.net/2009/09/26/aaa-heroes-inmortales-homenaje-a-antonio-pena-resultados-en-vivo-26-septiembre-2009-%C2%BFque-pasara-con-la-lucha-entre-charly-manson-y-chessman-%C2%BFquien-sera-el-luchador-sorpresa/ | title= AAA- Héroes Inmortales III- (Resultados en vivo 26 septiembre 2009) – Cibernético gana el Trofeo Antonio Peña – Electroshock sustituye a Charly Manson contra Chessman – El luchador sorpresa fue Konan Big | author= Marquina, Alva | date= September 26, 2009 | accessdate= September 27, 2009 | publisher= ''SuperLuchas'' Magazine| language=Spanish}}</ref> The 2005 show was the ninth Rey de Reyes show in the series.
===Storylines=== The Rey de Reyes show featured six [[Professional wrestling match types|professional wrestling matches]] with different wrestlers involved in pre-existing, scripted feuds, plots, and storylines. Wrestlers were portrayed as either [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heels]] (referred to as ''rudos'' in Mexico, those that portray the "bad guys") or [[Face (professional wrestling)|faces]] (''técnicos'' in Mexico, the "good guy" characters) as they followed a series of tension-building events, which culminated in a wrestling match or series of matches.

({{Age in years, months, weeks and days|month1=08|day1=15|year1=2012|month2=10|day2=07|year2=2012}}) |place = [[Rif Dimashq Governorate|Rif Dimashq]], [[Syria]] |coordinates = |map_type = |map_relief = |latitude = |longitude = |map_size = |map_marksize = |map_caption = |map_label = |territory = |result = Partial Syrian Army victory * Syrian Army seizes more than half a dozen rebel-held towns north, west and south of Damascus * Rebels retain control of the Ghouta area, east of Damascus * Rebels launch [[Rif Dimashq offensive (November 2012–February 2013)|their own offensive]] in mid-November |status = |combatant1 = {{flag|Syria}} *[[Syrian Armed Forces]] *[[Lijan militias]]{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/07/us-syria-crisis-militias-idUSBRE88612V20120907|title=Insight: Minority militias stir fears of sectarian war in Damascus|work=Reuters|accessdate=25 October 2014}} *Local police |combatant2 = {{flagicon|Syrian opposition}} [[Free Syrian Army]] *[[Damascus Military Council]] {{flagicon image|Flag of Jihad.svg}} [[Salafist jihadist]]s *{{flagicon image|Flag of the Al-Nusra Front.svg}} [[Al-Nusra Front]]{{cite news|title=Rebels fighting against al-Assad rule fragmented, disorganized in Syria |url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/images/Documents/F199BC38846F4E72B083A4222B568E7F.pdf |last=Yezdani |first=İpek |newspaper=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |date=2 September 2012 |accessdate=22 September 2012}} *{{Flagicon image|Original flag of Kata'ib Ahrar al-Sham.png}} [[Ahrar ash-Sham]] *Foreign fighters |commander1 = [[Maher al-Assad]] (WIA) |commander2 = Unknown |units1 = [[3rd Armoured Division (Syria)|3rd Armoured Division]]
